note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Sir Perfidious Old-craft an old Knight, and Witty-pate his Sonne.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: _SIr i'me no Boy, i'me deepe in one and twenty,
The ſecond yeare's approaching.

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: A fine time
For a youth to live by his wits then I ſhould thinke,
If e're he meane to make account of any.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Wits Sir?

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: I wits Sir, if it be ſo ſtrange to thee,
I'me ſorry I ſpent that time to get a Foole,
I might have imploy'd my paines a great deale better;
Thou know'ſt all that I have I ha got by my wits,
And yet to ſee how urgent thou art too;
It grieves me thou art ſo degenerate
To trouble me for meanes, I never offer'd it:
My Parents from a Schoole-boy, paſt nineteen once,
See what theſe times are growne too, before twenty
I ruſht into the world, which is indeed
Much like the Art of Swimming, he that will atteine to't
Muſt fall plumpe, and duck himſelfe at firſt,
And that will make him hardy and adventurous,
And not ſtand putting in one foot and ſhiver,
And then draw tother after, like a quake-buttock;
Well he may make a padler i' the world,
From hand to mouth, but never a brave ſwimmer,
Borne up by th' chin as I bore up my ſelf▪
With my ſtrong induſtry that never fayl'd me;
For he that lyes borne up with Patrimonies,
Lookes like a long great Aſſe that ſwims with bladders,
Come but one prick of adverſe fortune to him
He ſinkes, becauſe he never try'd to ſwim
When wit playes with the billowes that choackt him.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Why is it not a faſhion for a Father Sir,
Out of his yearely thouſands, to allow
His only ſonne a competent brace of hundreds,
Or ſuch a toy?

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: Yes, if he meane to ſpoyle him,
Or mar his wits he may, but never I
This is my humour Sir, which you'le finde conſtant;
I love wit ſo well becauſe I liv'd by't,
That ile give no man power out of my meanes to hurt it,
And that's a kinde of gratitude to my rayſer,
Which great ones oft forget; I admire much
This Ages dulneſſe, when I ſcarce writ man,
The firſt degree that e're I tooke in thriving,
I lay intelligencer cloſe for wenching,
Could give this Lord or Knight a true Certificate
Of all the Maiden-heads extant, how many lay
'Mongſt Chamber-maids, how many 'mongſt Exchange Wenches,
Though never many there I muſt confeſſe,
They have a trick to utter ware ſo faſt;
I knew which Lady had a minde to fall,
Which Gentlewoman new divorc'ſt, which Tradeſ-man breaking,
The price of every ſinner to a haire,
And where to raiſe each price; which were the Tearmers
That would give Velvet Petty-coates, Tiſſue Gownes,
Which Peeces, Angells, Suppers, and Halfe crownes;
I knew how to match and make my market,
Could give intelligence where the Pox lay ledger,
And then to ſee the Letchers ſhift a point,
'Twas ſport and profit too; how they would ſhun
Their ador'd Miſtris chambers, and run fearefully,
Like Rats from burning houſes, ſo brought I
My Clyents a the game ſtill ſafe together,
And noble Gameſters lov'd me, and I felt it:
Give me a man that lives by his wits ſay I,
And never left a Groat, there's the true Gallant.
When I grew ſomewhat purſie, I grew then
In mens opinions too, and confidences,
They put things call'd Executorſhips upon me,
The charge of Orphans, little ſenceleſſe creatures,
Whom in their Childe-hoods I bound forth to Felt-makers,
To make 'em loſe and work away their Gentry,
Diſguiſe their tender natures with hard cuſtome,
So wrought 'em out in time, there I rizze ungently,
Nor do I feare to diſcourſe this unto thee,
I'me arm'd at all points againſt treachery,
I hold my humour firme, if I can ſee thee thrive by
Thy wits while I live, I ſhall have the more courage
To truſt thee with my Lands when I dye; if not,
The next beſt wit I can heare of carries 'em:
For ſince in my time and knowledge ſo many rich Chil|dren
Of the City conclude in beggery, i'de rather
Make a wiſe ſtranger my Executor, then a fooliſh
Sonne my Heire, and to have my Lands call'd after my
Wit, thou after my name; and that's my nature.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange harſh one, muſt I ſtill ſhift then?
I come brave cheates, once to my trade agen,
And i'le ply't harder now then e're I did for't,
You'le part with nothing then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: Not a jot Sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: If I ſhould aske you bleſſing e're I go Sir,
I think you would not give't me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Let me but heare thou liv'ſt by thy wits once
Thou ſhalt have any thing, thou'rt none of mine elſe,
Then why ſhould I take care for thee?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: 'Thanke your bounty. Exit

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: So wealth love me, and long life, I beſeech it,
As I do love the man that lives by his wits,
He comes ſo neare my nature; i'me growne old now,
And ev'n arriv'd at my laſt cheat I feare me,
But 'twill make ſhift to bury me, by day-light too,
And diſcharge all my Legacies, 'tis ſo wealthy,
And never trouble any Intereſt money:
Iv'e yet a Neece to wed, over whoſe ſteps
I have plac'ſt a truſty watchfull Gardineſſe,
For feare ſome poore Earle ſteale her, 't has bin threatned
To redeem morgag'd Land, but he ſhall miſſe on't;
To prevent which, I have ſought out a match for her,
Fop of Fop-hall, he writes himſelfe, I take it,
The antient, ſt Fop in England, with whom i'me privately
Compounded for the third part of her Portion,
sp.stage: Enter Sir Gregory Fop, and Cuningham.
sp.l: And ſhe ſeemes pleas'd, ſo two parts reſt with me,
Hee's come; Sir Gregory, welcome, what's he Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Young Cunningham, a Norfolke Gentleman,
One that has liv'd upon the Fops, my kinred,
Ever ſince my remembrance; hee's a wit indeed,
And we all ſtrive to have him, nay, 'tis certaine
Some of our name has gone to Law for him;
Now 'tis my turne to keep him, and indeed
Hee's plaguy chargeable as all your wit, are,
But I will give him over when I liſt,
I ha us'd wits ſo before.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Hope when y'are married Sir you'le ſhake him off.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why what do you take me to be, old Father i'Law that ſhall be, do you think ile have any of the Wits hang upon nie after I am married once? none of my kinred ever had before me; but where's this Neece? iſt a faſhion in London to marry a woman and never ſee her?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Excuſe the niceneſſe Sir, that care's your friend,
Perhaps had ſhe Been ſeen, you had never ſeen her;
There's many a ſpent-thing call'd an't like your honour,
That lyes in wait for her at firſt ſnap, ſhe's a Counteſſe,
Drawne with ſixe Mares through Fleet-ſtreete, and a Coach-man,
Sitting Bare-headed to their Flaunders buttocks,
This whets him on.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Pray let's clap up the buſineſſe Sir,
I long to ſee her, are you ſure you have her,
Is ſhe not there already? Hark, O hark.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How now, what's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir. Greg.
sp.l: Every Caroach goes by,
Goes ev'n toth' heart of me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Ile have that doubt eas'd Sir,
Inſtantly cas'd, Sir Gregory, and now I think on't
A toy comes i' my minde, ſeeing your friend there,
Wee'l have a little ſport, give you but way to't,
And put a trick upon her, I love wit pretiouſly,
You ſhall not be ſeene yet, wee'le ſtale your friend firſt,
If't pleaſe but him to ſtand for the Anti-maske.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Puh, he ſhall ſtand for any thing, why his ſupper
Lyes i' my breeches here, ile make him faſt elſe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Then come you forth more unexpectedly
The Maske it ſelfe, a thouſand a yeare joynture,
The cloud your friend will be then drawne away,
And only you the beauty of the Play.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: For Red and Black Ile put downe all your Fuller
Let but your Neece bring White, and we have three Cullours. Exit Sir Greg.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'me given to underſtand you are a Wit Sir.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.l: I'me one that Fortune ſhewes ſmall favour to Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why there you conclude it, whether you will or no Sir;
To tell you truth, i'me taken with a wit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Fowlers catch Woodcocks ſo, let not them know ſo much,

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A Peſtilence mazard, a Duke Humphrey ſparke
Had rather loſe his Dinner then his Jeſt,
I ſay, I love a wit the beſt of all things.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: AlwaieS except your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Has gin't me twice now,
All with a breath, I thank him; but that I love a wit
I ſhould be heartily angry; cuds, my Neece,
You know the buſineſſe with her,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: With a woman?
'Tis ev'n the very ſame it was i'me ſure
Five thouſand yeares a go, no foole can miſſe it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman I promiſt Neece,
To preſent to your affection.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Ware that Arrow.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Deliver me the truth now of your liking.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'me ſpoyl'd already, that ſuch poore leane Game
Should be found out as I am.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Go ſet too her Sir—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: How noble is this vertue in you Lady,
Your eye may ſeeme to commit thouſand ſlaughters
On your dull ſervants, which truly taſted
Conclude all in comforts.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Puh.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: It rather ſhewes what a truth worth can make,
Such as yours is.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And that's not worth a groat,
How like you him Neece?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: It ſhall appeare how well Sir,
I humbly thanke you for him.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Hah? ha, good gullory, he does it well ifaith,
Light, as if he meant to purchaſe lip-land there:
Hold, hold, beare off I ſay, ſlid your part hangs too long.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: My joyes are mockcries.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Y'ave ●●th expreſt a worthy care and love Sir,
Had mine owne eye been ſet at liberty,
To make a publike choyce (beleeve my truth Sir)
It could not ha done better for my heart
Then your good providence has.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You will ſay ſo then,
Alaſſe ſweet Neece, all this is but the ſcahbard,
Now I draw forth the weapon.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Sir Gregory,
Approach thou Lad of thouſands.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: What motion's this? the Modell of Ninivie?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Accoſt her daintily now, let me adviſe thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I was advis'd to beſtow dainty coſt on you.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You were ill advis'd, back, and take better counſell;
You may have good for an Angell, the leaſt coſt
You can beſtow upon a woman Sir
Trebles ten Counſellors Fees, in Lady-ware,
Y'are over head and eares ere you be aware,
Faith keep a Batchelour ſtill, and go to bowles Sir,
Follow your Miſtris there, and prick and ſave Sir,
For other Miſtreſſes will make you a ſlave Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: So, ſo, I have ray lerrepoop already.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why how now Neece, this is the man I tell you.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: He, hang him Sir, I know you do but mocke,
This is the man you would ſay.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: The Devill rides I think.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I muſt uſe cunning here.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Make me not mad, uſe him with all reſpect,
This is the man I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Would you could perſwade me to that;
Alaſſe, you cannot go beyond me Unckle.
You carry a leſt well I muſt confeſſe,
For a man of your yeares, but—

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'me wrought beſide my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I never beheld comlineſſe till this minute.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.l: O good ſweet Sir, pray offer not theſe wards
To an old Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Away fifteene,
Here's fifty one exceeds thee.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: What's the buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Give me theſe motherly creatures, come, ne're ſmother it,
I know you are a teeming woman yet.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Troth a young Gent. might do much I think Sir

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Go too then.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: And I ſhould play my part, or I were ingratefull.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Can you ſo ſoone neglect me?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Hence, i'me buſie.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This croſſe point came in luckely, impudent Baggage.
Hang from the Gentleman, art thou not aſham'd
To be a Widowes hinderance?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Are you angry Sir?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You're welcome, pray court on, I ſhall deſire
Your honeſt wiſe acquaintance; vexe me not
After my care and paines to finde a match for thee,
Leſt I confine thy life to ſome out chamber,
Where thou ſhalt waſte the ſweetneſſe of thy youth,
Like a conſuming light in her owne ſocket,
And not allow'd a male creature about thee;
A very Munckey thy neceſſity
Shall prize at a thouſand pound a Chimney-ſweeper
At fifteene hundred.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: But are you ſerious Unckle?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Serious.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Pray let me looke upon the gentleman
With more heed, then I did but hum him over
In haſte, good faith, as Lawyers Chancery ſheetes;
Beſhrew my blood a tollerable man,
Now I diſtinctly read him.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Say he be black, hee's of a very good pitch,
Well anckled, two good confident calves, they looke
As if they would not ſhrink at the ninth childe;
The redneſſe ith' face, why that's in faſhion,
Moſt of your high bloods have it, ſigne of greatneſſe marry;
'Tis to be taken downe too with May butter,
Ile ſend to my Lady Spend-tayle for her Medicine.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum te dum, dum, dum, de dum.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Hee's qualified too, beleve me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum to dum, de dum, de dum.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Where was my judgement?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum te dum, dum, dum, te dum, te dum.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Perfections cover'd meſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum te dum, te dum, te dum.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: It ſmoakes apparantly, pardon ſweet Sir
The errour of my Sex.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why well ſaid Neece,
Upon ſubmiſſion you muſt pardon her now Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Ile do't by courſe, do you think i'me an aſſe Knight?
Here's firſt my hand, now't goes to the Seale Office.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Formally finiſht, how goes this Suit forward?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'me taking meaſure of the widowes minde Sir,
I hope to fit her heart.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Who would have dreamt
Of a young morſell now? things come in minutes.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Truſt him not widow, hee's a younger Brother,
Hee'le ſweare and lye; beleeve mo hee's worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: He brings more content to a woman with that nothing,
Then he that brings his thouſands without any thing,
We have preſidents for that amongſt great Ladies.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Come, come, no Language now ſhall be in faſhion,
But your Love-phraſe the bell to procreation. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Ruinous Gentry, Witty-pate, and Priſcian.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Pax, there's nothing puts me beſides my wits, but this fourth,
This lay illiterate ſhare, there's no conſcience in 't.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Sir, it has ever been ſo where I have practis'd, and muſt be
Sill where I am, nor has it been undeſerv'd at the yeares
End, and ſhuffle the Almanack together, vacations and
Terme-times one with another, though I ſay't, my wife is a
Woman of a good ſpirit, then it is no lay-ſhare.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Faith for this five yeare, Ego poſſum probare, I have had
A hungry penurious ſhare with em, and ſhe has had as much
As I alwayes.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Preſent or not preſent?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: And what preſident's this for me? becauſe your Hic & hac, Turpis and Qui mihi diſcipulus braines (that never got any thing but by accidence and uncertainty) did allow it, therefore I muſt, that have grounded con|cluſions of wit, hereditary rules for my Father to get by.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Sir be compendious, either take or refuſe, I will bate no token of my wives ſhare, make even the laſt recko|nings, and either ſo unite or here devide company.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: A good reſolution, profecto, let every man beg his owne way, and happy man be his dole.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Well, here's your double ſhare, and ſingle brains Pol, edipo, here's toward, a Caſter ecaſtor for you, I will endure it a forthnight longer, but by theſe juſt five ends—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Take heed, five's odde, put both hands together or ſeverally they are all odde unjuſt ends.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p:
Medeius ſidius, hold your tongue, I depoſe you from halfe a ſhare preſently elſe, I will make you a parti|ciple and decline you, now you underſtand me, be you a quiet conjunction amongſt the undeclined; you and your Latine ends ſhall go ſhift, Solus cum ſolo together elſe, and then if ever they got ends of gold and ſilver enough to
ſerve that Gerundine maw of yours, that without Do will end in Di & Dum inſtantly.

div.stage: Enter Old Knight and Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Inough, ynough, here comes company, we loſe five ſhares in wrangling about one.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: My Father, put on Priſcian, he has Latine frag|ments too, but I feare him not, ile caſe my face with a lit|tle more haire and releive.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Tuſh Nephew (ile call you ſo) for if there be
No other obſtacles then thoſe you ſpeake of
They are but powder charges without pellets,
You may ſafely front 'em; and warrant your owne danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: No other that I can perceive ifailh Sir, for I put her to't, and felt her as far as I could, and the ſtron|geſt repulſe was, ſhe ſaid, ſhe would have a little Souldier in me, that (if need were) I ſhould defend her repu|tation.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And ſurely Sir, that is a principle
Amongſt your principall Ladies, they require
Vallour either in a friend or a husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: And I allow their requeſts ifaith, as well as a|ny womans heart can deſire, if I knew where to get va|lour, I would as willingly entertaine it as any man that blowes.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Breathes, breathes Sir, that's the ſweeter phraſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Blowes for a Souldier, ifaith Sir, and i'me in
Practiſe that way.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: For a Souldier, I grant it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Slid ile ſwallow ſome bullets, and good round ones too, but ile have a little Souldier in me.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Will you on and beg, or ſteale and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: And ſome Schollar ſhe would have me beſides,
Tuſh, that ſhall be no bar, 'tis a quality in a
Gentleman, but of the leaſt queſtion.

sp.speaker: O. K.

l.hi: Salvete dicis ad nos? fubeo te ſalvere,

sp.l: Nay Sir, we have Latine and other mettall in us too,
Sir, you ſhall ſe talke with this fellow now.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I could finde in my heart to talk with him too,
If I could underſtand him.

l.hi: Charitatis veſtrae eſtote poopitii in me junenem,

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: A pretty Schollar by my faith Sir, but ile to him agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Does he beg or ſteale in this Language can you tell Sir?
He may take away my good name from me, and I ne're
The wiſer.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: He begs, he begs Sir.

l.hi: Ecce, ecce, in oculis lacrymarum flumen, in ore
Fames, ſitiſq. ignis in vultu, pudor & impudentia,

sp.speaker: O. K.

l.hi: Audi tu bonus ſocius, tu es Scolaſticus, ſic intelligo,

sp.l: Ego faciam argumentum, mark now Sir, now I fetch
Him up.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I have been fetcht up a hundred times for this,
Yet I could never learne halfe ſo much.

sp.speaker: O. K.

l.hi: Audi, & reſponde, hoc eſt Argumentum, nomen eſt
Nomen, ergo, quod eſt tibi nomen, Reſponde nunc,

sp.l: Reſponde argumentum meum. Have I not put him to't Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Step in, the raſcall is put out of his pen'd ſpeech,
And he can go no farther.

p.hi: Oh Domine, tanta mea eſt miſeria.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: So he's almoſt in agen.

l.hi: Ʋt nocte mecum pernoctat egeſtas, luce quotidie
Sed quid eſt tibi nomen, & quis dedit? Reſponde

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: He's dry, he hems, on quickly.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Courteous Gentlemen, if the brow of a Military face may not be offenſive to your generous eye-balls, let his wounds ſpeake better then his words, for ſome branch or ſmall ſprig of charity to be planted upon this poore barren ſoyle of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: How now, what Armes and Arts both go a beg|ing?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Such is the poaſt-progreſſe of cold charity now a dayes, who (for heat to her frigid limbs) paſſes in ſo ſwift a motion, that two at the leaſt had need be to ſtay her.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sir, let's reward um I pray you and be gone, if any quarrell ſhould ariſe amongſt us, I am able to an|ſwer neither of them, his Iron and Steele tongue is as hard as the tothers Latine one.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay Sir, I will talke a little with him firſt,
Let me alone with both, I will try whether they
Live by their wits or no; for ſuch a man I love,
And what? you both beg together then?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: With equall fortunes equall diſtribution, there's not the breadth of a ſwords point uneven in our divi|ſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What two qualities are here caſt away upon two poore fellowes, if a man had um that could maintaine um, what a double man were that, if theſe two Fellowes might be bought and ſodden, and boyl'd to a jelly, and eaten faſting every morning, I do not thinke but a man ſhould finde ſtrange things in his ſtomack.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Come Sir, joyne your charity with mine, and we'le make up a couple of pence betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: If a man could have a penny-worth for his pen|ny, I would beſtow more money with 'em.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Save you Gentlemen, how now? what are you en|countred here? what fellowes are theſe?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: 'Faith Sir, here's Mars and Mercury, a paire of poore Planets it ſeemes, that Jupiter has turn'd out to live by their wits, and we are e'ne about a little ſparke of charity to kindle um a new fire.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Stay, pray you ſtay Sir, you may abuſe your cha|rity, nay make that goodneſſe in you no better then a vice, ſo many deceivers walke in theſe ſhadowes now a dayes, that certainly your bounties were better ſpilt then reſerv'd to ſo lewd and vicious uſes; which is he that pro|feſſes the Souldier?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: He that profeſſes his owne profeſſion Sir, and the dangerous life he hath led in it this paire of halfe ſcore yeares.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: In what ſervices have you been Sir?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: The firſt that fleſht me a ſouldier Sir, was that great battell at Aleazar in Barbarie, where the noble Eng|liſh Stukely fell, and where that royall Portugall Sebaſtian ended his untimely dayes.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Are you ſure Sebaſtian dyed there?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Faith Sir, there was ſome other rumour hop't a-amongſt us, that he wounded eſcap't, and touch't on his Native ſhore agen, where finding his Country at home more diſtreſt by the invaſion of the Spaniard then his loſſe abroad, forſooke it, ſtill ſupporting a miſerable and un|fortunate life, which (where he ended) is yet uncer|taine.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: By my faith Sir, he ſpeakes the neareſt ſame of truth in this.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Since Sir, I ſerv'd in France, the Low Countries, laſtly, at that memorable Skirmiſh at Newport, where the forward and bold Scot there ſpent his life ſo freely, that from every ſingle heart that there fell, came home from his reſolution a double honour to his country.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: This ſhould be no counterfeit, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I do not thinke he is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: But Sir, me thinkes you do not ſhew the markes of a Souldier, could you ſo freely ſcape, that you brought home no ſcarres to be your chronicle?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Sir, I have wounds and many, but in thoſe parts where nature and humanity bids me ſhame to publiſh.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: A good Souldier cannot want thoſe badges.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Now am not I of your minde in that, for I hold him the beſt ſouldier that ſcapes beſt, alwaies at a Cocke-fencing I give him the beſt that has the feweſt knocks.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nay ile have a bout with your Schollar too,
To aske you why you ſhould be poore (yet richly learn'd)
Were no queſtion, at leaſt you can eaſily
Anſwer it; but whether you have learning enough,
To deſerve to be poore or no (ſince poverty is
Commonly the meed of Learning) is yet to be trye'd;
You have the Languages, I meane the chiefe,
As the Hebrew, SyriacK, Greeke, Latine, &c.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: The Latine I have ſufficiently tryed him in,
And I promiſe you Sir he is very well grounded.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I will prove him in ſome of the reſt.

p.hi: Kay yonkeron niggitton oy fouleroi Aſiniſoy.
Tous pollous ſtrikerous, Angelo to peeſo.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Certainely Sir, a very excellent Schollar in the Greeke.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I do note a wonderous readineſſe in him.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I do wonder how the Trojans could hold out ten yeares Seige (as 'tis reported) againſt the Greekes, if Achilles ſpoke but this Tongue? I do not thinke but he might have ſhaken downe the walls in a ſeventh-night, and ne're troubled the wooden horſe.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I will try him ſo far as I can in the Syriack.

l.hi: Kircom bragmen, ſhag a dou ma dell mathou.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Gentlemen I have done, any man that can, go further,
I confeſſe my ſelfe at a Nonplus.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Faith not I Sir, I was at my fartheſt in my naturall Language, I was never double-tongu'd I thanke my hard fortune.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, 'tis pitty (walke further off a little my friends) I ſay, 'tis pitty ſuch fellowes ſo endow'd, ſo qualified with the gifts of Nature and Arts, yet ſhould have ſuch a ſcarcity of fortunes benefits, we muſt blame our Iron-hearted age for it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty indeed, and our pitty ſhall ſpeake a little for 'em;
Come Sir, here's my Groat.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: A Groat Sir? oh fie, give nothing rather, 'twere better you rayl'd on um for begging and ſo quit your ſelfe, I am a popre Gentleman, that have little but my wits to live on.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Troth and I love you the better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Yet ile begin a better example then ſo, here fellowes, there's between you, take Purſe and all, and I would it were heavier for your ſakes, there's a paire of Angells to guide you to your lodgings, a poore Gentle|mans good will.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: This is an ill example for us, Sir, I would this bountifull Gentleman had not come this way to day.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Pox, we muſt not ſhame our ſelves now, Sir, ile give as much as that Gentleman, though I never be Souldier or Schollar while I live; here friends, there's a piece, that if he were divided would make a paire of Angells for me too, in the love I beare to the Sword and the Tongues.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: My largeſſe ſhall be equall too, and much good doe you, this bounty is a little abatement of my wit though, I feele that.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: May ſouldiers ever defend ſuch charities.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: And Schollars pray for their encreaſe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir, theſe fellowes may pray for you, you have made the Schollars commons exceed to day, and a word with you, Sir, you ſaid you liv'd by your wits, if you uſe this bounty you'le begger your wits be|leeve it.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I hope to encreaſe 'em by it, this ſeed never wants his harveſt, fare you well, Sir. Exit

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I thinke a man were as good meer with a reaſonable Thiefe, as an unreaſonable Begger ſometimes, I could finde in my heart to beg halfe mine back agen, can you change my piece my friends?

p.hi: Tempora mutantur, & nos mutamur in illis.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: My Gold is turn'd into Latine,
Looke you good fellowes, here's one round
Shilling more that lay conceal'd.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Sir, away, we ſhall be drawn farther into dam|mage elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: A pox of the Foole, he live by his wits? if his wits leave him any money but what he beggs or ſteales ve|ry ſhortly, ile be hang'd for him.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: This breakfaſt parcell was well fetcht of ifaith.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Tuſh, a by-blow for mirth, we muſt have better purchaſe, we want a fourth for another project that I have ripen'd.

sp.speaker: Ruin,
sp.p: My wife, ſhe ſhares, and can deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: She can change her ſhape, and be maſculine.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the free'ſt conditions, ſhe feares not the crack of a Piſtoll, ſhe dares ſay ſtand to a Grazier.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Good, then you Sir Bacchus, Appollo ſhall be diſpatcht with her ſhare, and ſome contents to meete us to morrow (at a certaine place and time appointed) in the maſculine Gender, my Father has a Nephew, and I an owne Couſen comming up from the Univerſity, whom he loves moſt indulgently, eaſie Maſter Credulous Oldcraft, (for you know what your meere Academique is) your Carrier never miſſes his houre, he muſt not be rob'd (be|cauſe he has but little to loſe) but he muſt joyne with us in a deviſe that I have, that ſhall rob my Father of a hundred pieces, and thanke me to be rid on't, for there's the ambition of my wit to live upon his profeſt wit, that has turn'd me out to live by my wits.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: A male habit, a bag of a hunder'd weight, though it be counters (for my Alchimy ſhall turne 'em into Gold of my Fathers) the houre, the place, the action ſhall be at large ſet downe, and Father, you ſhall know, that I put my portion to uſe, that have given me to live by;
And to confirme your ſelfe in me renate,
I hope you'le finde my wits legitimate. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: NAy Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Put me not in minde on't prethee,
You cannot do a greater wrong to women,
For in our wants, 'tis the moſt chiefe affliction
To have that name remembred; 'tis a title
That miſery workes us by, and the worlds malice,
Scorne and contempt has not where with to work
On humble Callings; they are ſafe, and lye
Levell with pitty ſtill, and pale diſtreſſe
Is no great ſtranger to 'em; but when fortune
Lookes with a ſtormy face on our conditions,
We finde affliction worke, and envie paſtime,
And our worſt enemy then that moſt abuſes us,
Is that we are call'd by, Lady, O my ſpirit,
Will nothing make thee humble? I am well methinkes,
And can live quiet with my fate ſometimes,
Untill I looke into the world agen,
Then I begin to rave at my ſtars bitterneſſe,
To ſee how many muck hills plac'd above me;
Peaſants and Droyles, Caroches full of Dunghills,
Whoſe very birth ſtinkes in a geenerous noſtrill,
Gliſtring by night like Glow-wormes through the High-ſtreets,
Hurried by Torch-light in the Foot-mans hands
That ſhew like running Fire-drakes through the City,
And I put to my ſhifts and wits to live,
Nay ſometimes danger too; on Foot, on Horſe-back,
And earne my ſupper manfully ere I get it,
Many a meale I have purchas'd at that rate,
Fed with a wound upon me, ſtampt at midnight.
Hah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Now you rnay tell your ſelfe Lady. Pulls off's beard

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh Mr. Priſcian, what's the project,
For you ne're come without one.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Firſt, your Husband,
Sir Ruinous Gentry greetes you with beſt wiſhes,
And here has ſent you your full ſhare by me
In five Cheates, and two Robberies.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And what comes it too?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Neare upon thirteene pound.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A goodly ſhare.
'Twill put a, Lady ſcarce in Philip and Cheyney,
VVith three ſmall Bugle Laces, like a Chamber-maid,
Here's pretious lifing.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: 'Laſſe you muſt consider, Lady,
'Tis but young Tearm, Atturnies ha ſmall doings yet,
Then High-way Lawyers, they muſt needs ha little,
Wee'ne had ho great good luck to ſpeake troth Beauty,
Since your ſtout Lady-ſhip parted from 's at Hye-gate,
But there's a faire hope now for a preſent hunder'd,
Here's mans Apparrell, your Horſe ſtands at doore.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And what's the vertuous plot now?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Marry Lady,
You like a bvave young Gallant muſt be rob'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I rob'd?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Nay then—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well, well, go on, let's heare Sir.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Here's a ſeal'd bag of a Hunder'd, which indeed
Are Counters all, only ſome ſixteen Groates
Of white money i'the mouth on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So, what Saddle have I?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Mounſieur Laroon's the French-mans.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That agen,
You know ſo well itis not for my ſtride,
How oft have I complain'd on't?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: You nay have Jockey's then, the little Scotch one,
You muſt diſpatch. Exit Priſ.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ile ſoone by ready Sir,
Before you ha ſhifted Saddles, many women
Have their wealth flow to 'em, I was made I ſee
To help my fortune, not my fortune me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: My wayes are Goblin-led, and the night Elſe
Still drawee me from my home, yet I follow,
Sure 'tis not altogether fabulous,
Such Haggs do get dominion of our tongues
So ſoone as we ſpeake, the Inchantment bindes;
I have diſſembled ſuch a trouble on me,
As my beſt wits can hardly cleare agen;
Piping through this old Reede, the Gardianeſſe,
With purpoſe that my harmony ſhall reach
And pleaſe the Ladies eare, ſhe ſtops below,
And ecchoes back my love unto my lips,
Perſwaded by moſt violent arguments
Of ſelfe-love in her ſelfe; I am ſo ſelfe-foole,
To do at upon her hunder'd-wrinckl'd face;
I could begger her to accept the gifts
She would throw upon me; 'twere charity,
But for pitties ſake I will be a niggard
And undo, her, refuſing to take from her;
I'me haunted agen, if it take not now
I'le breake the Spell.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Sweet Cuningame, welcome;
What? a whole day abſent? Birds that build Neſts
Have care to keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: That's granted,
But not continually to ſit upon 'em;
Leſſe in the youngling ſeaſon, elſe they deſire
To fly abroad, and recreate their labours,
Then they returne with freſher appetite
To worke agen.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, well, you have built a neſt
That will ſtand all ſtormes, you need not miſtruſt
A weather-wrack, and one day it may be
The youngling ſeaſon too, then I hope
You'le ne're fly out of ſight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There will be paines,
I ſee to ſhake this Bur off, and ſweeteſt,
Prethee how fares thy charge? has my good friend
Sir Gregory the countenance of a Lover?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: No by my troth, not in my minde, me thinkes
(Setting his Worſhip aſide) he lookes like a foole.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay ifaith, ne're divide his Worſhip from him for that
Small matter; Foole and Worſhip are no ſuch
Strangers now adaies, but my meaning is,
Has he thy Ladies countenance of love?
Lookes ſhe like a welconie on him? plainely,
Have they as good hope of one another,
As Cupid bleſſe us, we have ?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Troth I know not,
I can perceive no forwardneſſe in my charge,
But I proteſt I wiſh the Knight better
For your ſake, Bird.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why thanks ſweet Bird, and with my heart I wiſh,
That he had as ſtrong and likely hope of her
As thou haſte of me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, he's like to ſpeed
Ne're the worſe for that good wiſh, and ile tell you
Bird (for ſecrets are not to be kept betwixt us two)
My charge thinkes well of you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Of me? for what?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: For my ſake, I meane ſo, I have heard her
A hundred times ſince her. Unckle gave her
The firſt bob about you, that ſhe'de do ſomewhat
For my ſake if things went well together,
We have ſpoke of doores and bolts, and things and things,
Go too, Ile tell you all, but you'le finde
Some advancement for my ſake I do beleeve.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Faith be not ſparing, tell me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: By my Lady
You ſhall pardon me for that, 'twere a ſhame
If men ſhould heare all that women ſpeakes behinde
Their backes ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You muſt give me leave yet,
At leaſt to give her thankes.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Not that neither,
She muſt not take a notice of my blabbing,
It is ſufficient you ſhall give me thankes,
For 'tis for my ſake if ſhe be bountifull,
She loves me, and loves you too for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: How ſhall I knowing this but be ingrate,
Not to reapy her with my deareſt duty.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I, but you muſt not know it, if you tell
All that I open to you, you'le ſhame us both;
A far off you may kiſſe your hand, bluſh, or ſo,
But I'le allow no nearer conference.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Whoope! you'le be jealous I perceive now.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.l: Jealous? why there'e no true love without it, Bird,
I muſt be jealous of thee, but for her,
(Were it within my duty to my Maſter)
I durſt truſt h er with the ſtrongeſt tempter,
And I dare ſweare her now as pure a Virgin
As e're was welcom'd to a marriage bed,
If thoughts may be untainted, hers are ſo.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And where's the cauſe of your feare then?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, well;
When things are paſt, and the wedding Torches
Lighted at matches, to kindle better fire,
Then Ile tell you more.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Come, come, I ſee further,
That if we were married you'de be jealous.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I proteſt I ſhould a little, but not of her,
It is the married woman (if you mark it)
And not the maid that longs, the appetite
Followes the firſt taſte, when we have reliſht
We wiſh cloying, the taſte once pleas'd before,
Then our deſire is whetted on to more,
But I reveale too much to you, ifaith Bird.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Not a whit 'faith, Bird, betwixt you and I,
I am beholding for bettering of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Nay you ſhall know more of me if you'le be rul'd,
But make not things common.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Vd' ſo, your Lady?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I, 'tis no matter, ſhe'le like well of this,
Our familiarity is her content.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: This preſent from Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: From my Maſter, the Worſhipfull right Sir Gre|gory Fop

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: A Ruffe? and what might be his high conceit
In ſending of a Ruffe?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I thinke he had two conceits in it forſooth, too high too
Low, Ruffe high, becauſe as the Ruffe does embrace yout
necke all day, ſo does he deſire to throw his Knightly armes.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: But then I leave him off a nights.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Why then he is ruffe low, a ruffian, a bold adven|terous errant to do any rough ſervice for his Lady.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: A witty and unhappy conceit, do's he meane
As he ſeemes to ſay unto that reverence? Toward
He does wooe her ſure. Cuning.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: To tell you truth Lady, his conceit was far better then I have blaz'd it yet.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Do you think ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Nay I know it forſooth, for it was two dayes ere he compaſs'd it, to finde a fitting preſent for your Lady|ſhip, was ſending once a very fine Puppy to you.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: And that he would have brought himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: So he would indeed, but then he alter'd his de|viſe, and ſent thiſ Ruffe, requeſting withall, that whenſo|ever it is foule, you (with your owne hands) would be|ſtow the ſtarching of it.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: Elſe ſhe wooes him, now his eyes ſhoots this way; And what was the reaſon for that Sir?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: There lyes his maine conceit, Lady, for ſayes he, In ſo doing ſhe cannot chuſe but in the ſtarching to clap it often between her hands, and ſo ſhe gives a great liking and applauſe to my preſent, whereas if I ſhould ſend a Puppy; ſhe ever calls it to her with Iriſt, hiſſe, hiſſe, which js a fearefull diſgrace, he drew the devile from a Play, at the Bull tother day.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: I marry Sir, this was a rich conceit indeed.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: And far fetch'd, therefore good for you Lady-

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: How now? which way looke you, Bird?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: At the Fdole Bird ſhall I hot look at the Foole?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: At the Foole and I here? what need that? pray look this way.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Ile fit him aptly, either ile awake
His wits (if he have any) or force him
To app●are (as yet I cannot think him)
Without any, Sirrah, tell me one thing true
That I ſahall aske you now, Was this deviſe
Your Maſters owne? I doubt his wit in it;
He's not ſo ingenious.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: His owne I aſſure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Nay, you muſt not lye.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Not with a Lady, i'de rather lye with you then lye with my Maſter, by your leave in ſuch a caſe as this.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Yet agen your eye?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The Foole makes mirth ifaith,
I would heare ſome.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come, you ſhall heare none but me.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Come hither friend, nay come neare me; did
Thy Maſter ſend thee to me? he may be wiſe,
But did not ſhee it much in that; men ſometimes
May wrong themſelves unawares, when they leaſt thinke on 't;
Was Ʋulcan ever ſo unwiſe, to ſend Mars
To be his ſpokeſman when he went a wooing ?
Send thee? heigh-ho, a pretty rowling eye.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I can turne up the white and the black too, and need be, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Why, here's an amorous noſe.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: You ſee the worſt of my noſe, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: A cheek, how I could put it now in dalliance,
A paire of lips, oh that we were uney'd,
I could ſuck Sugar from 'em, what a beard's here?
When will the Knight thy Maſter have ſuch a
Stampe of man-hood on his face? nay, do not bluſh.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but my fleſh and blood that riſes so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Death, ſhe courts the Foole.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Away, away, 'tis ſport, do not minde it.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, come be familiar;
I, here's a promiſing palme; what a ſoft
Handfull of pleaſure's here, here's Downe compar'd
With Flocks and quilted Straw, thy Knights fingers
Are leane mattrice rubbers to theſe Feathers,
I prethee let me leane my cheeke upon't,
What a ſoft pillow's here?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Hum, umh, hu, hum.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Why there's a courage in that lively paſſion,
Meaſure thee all o're, there's not a limbe
But has his full proportion; it is my voyce,
There's no compare betwixt the Knight and thee,
The goodlier man by halfe, at once now
I ſee thee all over.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: If you had ſeen me ſwim tother day on my back, you would have ſed you had ſeene, there was two Cham|bermaids that ſaw me, and my leggs by chance were tang|led in the flags, and when they ſaw how I was hang'd, they cryed out, O help the man for feare he be drown'd.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: They could do no leſſe in pitty, come, thine arme, wee'le walke together.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Blindneſſe of Love and Women, why ſhe dotes upon the Foole.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: What's that to you, minde her not.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Away you Burre.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Hang of Fleſhook, faſten thine itchy claſpe
On ſome dry Toad-ſtoole that will kindle with thee,
And burne together.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Oh abominable,
Why do you not love me?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No, never did?
I tooke thee downe a little way to
Enforce a Vomit from my offended ſtomack,
Now thou'rt up agen I loath thee filthily.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Oh Villaine.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why doſt thou not ſee a ſight
Would make a man abjure the ſight of women.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, he's vext; ha, ha, ha,
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Why doſt thou laugh?
Becauſe thou laugh'ſt, nothing elſe ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She has but mockt my folly, elſe ſhe findes not
The boſome of my purpoſe, ſome other way
Muſt make me know; ile try her, and may chance quit
The fine dexterity of her Lady-wit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Yes introth, I laught to think of thy Maſter,
Now, what he would think if he knew this?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: By my troth I laugh at him too, faith Sirrah, hee's but a foole to ſay the truth, though I ſay't that ſhould not ſay't.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Yes, thou ſhouldſt ſay truth, and I beleeve thee;
Well, for this time wee'le part, you perceive ſomething,
Our tongues betray our hearts, there's our weakneſſe,
But pray be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: As Mouſe in Cheeſe, or Gooſe in Hay ifaith.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Looke, we are cut off, there's my hand where my lips would be.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ile wink and think 'em thy lips, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Now Gardioneſſe, I need not aske where you have been.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O Lady, never was woman ſo abus'd

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Do'ſt thou heare Lady ſweet-heart, I had forgot to tell thee, if you will I will come back in the Evening?

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: By no meanes, come not till I ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: If there be any need, you may think of things when I am gone, I may be convey'd into your chamber, ile lye un|der the bed while midnight, or ſo, or you ſhall put me up in one of your little boxes, I can creep in at a ſmall hole.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: Theſe are things I dare not venter, I charge you on my love never come till I ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Verbum inſapienti, 'tis enough to the wiſe, nor I think it is not fit the Knight ſhould know any thing yet.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: By no meanes, pray you go now, we are ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: For the things that are paſt, let us uſe our ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Now ile make a firme triall of your love,
As you love me, not a word more at this time,
Not a ſillable, 'tis the ſeale of love, take heed.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum, hum —
Hum's loath to depart. Exit Clown.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: So, this pleaſant trouble's gone, now Gardianeſſe,
What? your eyes eaſing your heart, the cauſe woman?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: The cauſe is falſe man, Madam, oh Lady,
I have been gub'd in a ſhining Carbuncle,
A very Glo-worme, that I thought had ſire in't,
And 'tis as cold as Ice.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: And juſtly ſerv'd,
Would'ſt thou once think that ſuch an erring Spring
Would dote upon thine Autumne?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Oh, had you heard him
But proteſt.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: I would not have beleev'd him,
Thou might'ſt have perceiv'd how I mockt thy folly,
In wanton imitation with the Foole,
Go weepe the ſin of thy credulity,
Not of thy loſſe, for it was never thine,
And it is gaine to miſſe it; wert thou ſo dull?
Nay yet thou'rt ſtupid and uncapable,
Why thou wert but the bait to fiſh with, not
The prey, the ſtale to catch another Bird with.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Indeed he call'd me Bird.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Yet thou perceiv'ſt not,
It is your Neece he loves, would'ſt thou be made
A ſtakling Jade? 'tis ſhe, examine it,
Ile hurry all awry, and tread my path
Over unbeaten grounds, go levell to the mark,
Not by circuler bouts, rare things are pleaſing,
And rare's but ſeldome in the ſimple ſence,
But has her Emphaſis with eminence Exit.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: My Neece? ſhe the rivall of my abuſe?
My fleſh and blood wrong me? ile Aunt her for't;
Oh opportunity, thou bleſſeſt me
Now Gentlewoman, are you parted ſo ſoone?
Where's your friend I pray? your Cuningame?

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.l: What ſay you Aunt?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come, come, your Cuningame?
I am not blinde with age yet, nor deafe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Dumbe I am ſure you are not, what ayld you Ant?
Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: No, nor ſick, nor mad, nor in my wits, nor ſlee|ping, nor walking, nor nothing, nor any thing; I know not what I am, nor what I am not.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Mercy cover us, what do you meane Aunt?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I meane to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: On whom?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: On thee, Baggage.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Revenge ſhould follow injury,
Which never reacht ſo far as thought in me
Towards you Aunt.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Your cunning, minion,
Nor your Cuningame can either blinde me,
The gentle Begger loves you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Beſeech you,
Let me ſtay your errour, I begin to heare,
And ſhake off my amazement; if you think
That ever any paſſage treating love
Hath been betwixt us yet commenc't, any
Silent eye-glance that might but ſparkle fire,
So much as brother and ſiſter might meet with,
The lip-ſalute, ſo much as ſtrangers might
Take a farewell with, the commixed hands,
Nay, but the leaſt thought of the leaſt of theſe;
In troth you wrong your boſome, by that truth
(Which I thinke yet you durſt be bayle for in me,
If it were offered ye) I am as free
As all this proteſtation.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: If ever you'l believe truth: why, I thought he had ſpake love to you, and if his heart prompted his tongue, ſure I did heare ſo much.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Oh falſeſt man, Ixions plague fell on me,
Never by woman (ſuch a maſculine cloud)
So airy and ſo ſubtle was embrac't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: By no cauſe in me, by my life deere Aunt.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I believe you, then help in my revenge,
And you ſhall do't, or looſe my love for ever,
Ile have him quitted at his equall weapon,
Thou art young, follow him, bait his deſires
With all the Engines of a womans wit,
Stretch modeſty even to the higheſt pitch;
He cannot freeze at ſuch a flaming beauty;
And when thou haſt him by the amorous gills,
Thinke on my vengeance, choke up his deſires,
Then let his banquettings be Tantaliſme,
Let thy diſdaine ſpurne the diſſembler out;
Oh I ſhould clime my ſtars, and ſit above,
To ſee him burne to aſhes in his love.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This will be a ſtrange taſte, Aunt, and an
Unwilling labour, yet in your injunction
I am a ſervant to't.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Thou'lt undertak't?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, let the ſucceſſe commend it ſelfe hereafter.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Effect it Girle, my ſubſtance is thy ſtore,
Nothing but want of will makes woman poore. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Why Pompey, thou art not ſtarke mad, art thou?
Wilt thou not tell me how my Lady doe's?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Your Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Did ſhe receive the thing that I ſent her kind|ly, or no?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: The thing that you ſent her, Knight, by the thing that you ſent, was for the things ſake that was ſent to carry the thing that you ſent, very kindly received, firſt, there is your Indenture, now go ſeeke you a ſervant: ſe|condly, you are a Knight: thirdly and laſtly, I am mine owne man: and fourthly, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Why Pompey? prethee let me ſpeak with thee,
Ile lay my life ſome Haire has croſt him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Knight, if you be a Knight, ſo keep you; as for the Lady, who ſhall ſay that ſhe is not a faire Lady, a ſweet Lady, an honeſt and a vertuous Lady, I will ſay he is a baſe fellow, a blab of his tongue, and I will make him eat theſe fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why here's no body ſaies ſo Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Whatſoever things have paſt betweene the Lady and the other party, whom I will not name at this time, I ſay ſhe is vertuous, and honeſt, and I will maintaine it, as long as I can maintaine my ſelfe with bread and water.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why I know no body thinks otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Any man that doe's but thinke it in my hearing, I will make him thinke on't while he has a thought in his Boſome; ſhall we ſay that kindneſſes from Ladies are common? or that favours and proteſtations are things of no moment betwixt parties and parties? I ſay ſtill, what|ſoever has been betwixt the Lady and the party which I will not name, that ſhe is honeſt, and ſhall be honeſt, what|ſoever ſhe doe's by day or by night, by light or by dark|neſſe, with cut and long tale.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why I ſay ſhe is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Is ſhe honeſt? in what ſenſe do you ſay ſhe is ho|neſt, Knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: If I could not finde in my heart to throw my Dagger at thy head, hilts and all, I'me an aſſe, and no Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Throw your Dagger at me! do not Knight, I give you faire warning, 'tis but caſt away if you do, for you ſhall have no other words of me, the Lady is an ho|neſt Lady, whatſoever reports may go of ſports and toyes, and thoughts, and words, and deeds, betwixt her and the party which I will not name; this I give you to under|ſtand, That another man may have as good an eye, as amorous a noſe, as faire a ſtampt beard, and be as proper a man as a Knight, (I name no parties) a Servingman may be as good as a Sir, a Pompey as a Gregory, a Doodle as a Fop; ſo Servingman Pompey Doodle may be reſpected as well with Ladies (though I name no parties) as Sir Gregory Fop; ſo farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: If the fellow be not out of his wits, then will I never have any more wit while I live; either the ſight of the Lady has gaſter'd him, or elſe he's drunke, or elſe he walks in his ſleepe, or elſe he's a foole, or a knave, or both, one of the three I'me ſure 'tis; yet now I think on't, ſhe has not us'd me ſo kindly as her Uncle promiſ'd me ſhe ſhould, but that's all one, he ſaies I ſhall have her, and I dare take his word for the beſt Horſe I have, and that's a weightier thing then a Lady, I'me ſure on't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lady Ruinous (as a man) Witty Pate, Sir Rui|nous, Priſcian, and Maſter Credulous, (binding and robing her, and in Scarfes) Credulous findes the bagge.

sp.speaker: Lady Ruin.
sp.l: Nay, I am your owne, 'tis in your pleaſure
How you'l deale with me; yet I would intreat,
You will not make that which is bad enough,
Worſe then it need be, by a ſecond ill,
When it can render you no ſecond profit;
If it be coyne you ſeeke, you have your prey,
All my ſtore, I vow, (and it weighs a hundred)
My life, or any hurt you give my body,
Can inrich you no more.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: You may purſue.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: As I am a Gentlewoman, I never will,
Onely wee'l binde you to quiet behaviour
Till you call out for Bayle, and on th'other
Side of the hedge leave you; but keep the peace
Till we be out of hearing, for by that
We ſhall be out of danger, if we come back,
We come with a miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You need not feare me.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Come, wee'l beſtow you then. Exit Ruin. Priſ. and Lady.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Why law you Sir, is not this a ſwifter Revenue then Sic probas ergo's & igitur's can bring in? why is not this one of your Syllogiſmes in Barbara? Omne utile eſt ho|neſtum.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Well Sir, a little more of this acquaintance,
Will make me know you fully I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You have (at firſt ſight) made me conſcious
Of ſuch a deed my dreames ne're prompted, yet
I could almoſt have wiſht rather ye'ad rob'd me
Of my Cloake, (for my Purſe 'tis a Schollers)
Then to have made me a robber.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I had rather have anſwered three difficult queſti|ons,
Then this one, as eaſie as yet it ſeems.

sp.speaker: W●tty.
sp.l: Tuſh, you ſhall never come to further anſwer for't;
●an you confeſſe your penurious Uncle,
〈◊〉 his full face of love, to be ſo ſtrict
〈◊〉 Nigard to your Commons, that you are faine
To ſize your belly out with ſhoulder fees?
With Rumps and Kidneyes, and cues of ſingle Beere,
And yet make Dayn●y to feed more daintily,
A● this eaſier rate? fie Maſter Credulous,
I bluſh for you.

sp.speaker: C●ed.
sp.l: This is a truth undeniable.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why go to then, I hope I know your Uncle,
How doe's he uſe his Sonne, nearer then you?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith like his Jade, upon the bare Commons,
Turn'd out to pick his living as he can get it;
He would have been glad to have ſhar'd in ſuch
A purchaſe, and thankt his good fortune too;
But mum no more — is all ſafe, Bullies?
Secure? the Gentleman thinks him moſt happy in his loſſe,
With his ſafe life and limbs▪ and redoubles
〈◊〉 firſt vow, as he is a Gentleman,
Never to purſue us.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well away then,
Diſperſe you with Maſter Credulous, who ſtill
Shall beare the purchaſe, Priſcian and I
Will take ſome other courſe: You know our meeting
At the Three Cups in Saint Gyles, with this proviſo,
(For 'tis a Law with us) that nothing be open'd
Till all be preſent, the looſer ſaies a hundred,
And it can weigh no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Come, Sir, wee'l be your guide.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: My honeſty, which till now was never forfeited,
All ſhall be cloſe till our meeting. Exit Cred. and Ruin.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Tuſh, I believ't,
And then all ſhall out; where's the theefe that's rob'd?

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Here Maſter Old●raft, all followes now.

sp.speaker: W●t.
sp.p: 'Twas neatly done, wench, now to turne that bag 〈◊〉 counterfets to current pieces, & actum eſt.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: You are the Chymiſt, wee'l blow the fire ſtill,
If you can mingle the ingredients.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I will not miſſe a cauſe, a quantity, a dram,
You know the place.
I have told her that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Good, turne Ruinous to be a Conſtable, I'me ſure
〈…〉 not beards of all ſorts, from the
Worſhipfull Magiſtrate to the under Watchman;
●ecauſe we muſt have no danger of life,
〈◊〉 cleanly cheat, attach Credulous,
〈◊〉 cauſe is plaine, the theft found about him;
●●en fall I in his owne Cozens ſhape
〈◊〉●eere accident, where finding him diſtreſt,
● w●●h ſome difficulty muſt fetch him off,
With promiſe that his Uncle ſhall ſhut up all
With double reſtitution: Maſter Conſtable, Ruinous
His mouth ſhall be ſtop't; you, Miſtris rob theef●,
Shall have your ſhare of what we can pull my father of;
Is't plaine enough?

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: As plaine a cozenage as can be, ſaith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Father, I come againe, and againe when this is
Paſt too, Father, one will beget another;
I'de be loath to leave your poſterity barren,
You were beſt to come to compoſition Father,
Two hundred pieces yearly allow me yet,
It will be cheaper (Father) then my wit,
For I will cheate none but you, deare Father.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Old Knight and Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: WHy now you take the courſe Sir Gregory Fop:
I could enforce her and I liſt, but love
That's gently wonne, is a mans owne for ever,
Have you prepar'd good muſick?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: As fine a noyſe, Uncle, as heart can wiſh▪

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why that's done like a Suitor,
They muſt be woo'd a hundred ſeverall waies,
Before you obtaine the right way in a woman,
'Tis an odde creature, full of creeks and windings.
The Serpent has not mo●e; for ſh'as all his,
And then her owne beſide came in by her mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A fearefull portion for a man to venter on.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: But the way found once by the wits of men,
There is no creature lyes ſo tame agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I promiſe you, not a houſe-Rabbit, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: No ſucker on 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What a thing's that?
They're pretty Fooles I warrant, when they're tame
As a man can lay his lips to.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How were you bred, Sir?
Did you never make a foole of a Tenants daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Never i'faith, they ha' made ſome fooles for me,
And brought 'em many a time under their aprons.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: They could not ſhew you the way plainlier, I thinke,
To make a foole againe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: There's fooles enough, Sir,
Leſſe they were wiſer.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This is wondrous rare,
Come you to London with a Maiden-head, Knight?
A Gentleman of your ranke ride with a Cloak-bag?
Never an Hoſteſſe by the way to leave it with?
Nor Tapſters ſiſter? nor head Oſtlers wife?
What no body?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Well mockt old Wit Monger,
I keep it for your Neece.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Do not ſay ſo for ſhame, ſhee'l laugh at thee,
A wife ne're looks for't, 'tis a Batchellors penny,
He may giv't to a beggar-wench, i'th progreſſe time,
And never call'd to account for't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Would I'de knowne ſo much,
I could ha' ſtopt a beggars mouth by'th way,
That rail'd upon me 'cauſe I'de give her nothing—
What, are they come?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: And plac'd directly, Sir,
Under her window.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What may I call you Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A poore ſervant to the Violl, I'me the Voyce, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: In good time Maſter Voyce.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed good time doe's get the maſtery.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What Countryman Maſter Voyce?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, borne at Ely, we all ſet up in Ely,
But our houſe commonly breakes in Rutland Shire.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A ſhrewd place by my faith, it may well break your voyce,
It breaks many a mans back; come, ſet to your buſineſſe.
FAine would I wake you, Sweet, but feare
I ſhould invite you to worſe cheare;
In your dreames you cannot fare
Meaner then Muſick; no compare;
None of your ſlumbers are compil'de
Ʋnder the pleaſure makes a childe;
Your day-delights, ſo well compact,
That what you think, turnes all to act:
I'de wiſh my life no better play,
Your dreame by night, your thought by day.
Wake gently, wake,
Part ſoftly from your dreames;
The morning flies
To your faire eyes,
To take her ſpeciall beames.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I heare her up, here Maſter Voyce,
Pay you the Inſtruments, ſave what you can,
To keep you when you're crackt. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Who ſhould this be?
That I'me ſo much beholding to, for ſweetneſſe?
Pray Heaven it happens right.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Good morrow Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: An ill day and a thouſand come upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: 'Light that's ſixe hundred more then any Al|manack has.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Comes it from thee? it is the mangieſt Muſick
That ever woman heard.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay ſay not ſo Lady,
There's not an itch about 'em.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I could curſe
My attentive powers, for giving entrance to't;
There is no boldneſſe like the impudence
That's lock't in a fooles blood, how durſt you do this?
In conſcience I abus'd you as ſufficiently
As woman could a man; inſatiate Coxcombe,
The mocks, and ſpitefull language I have given thee,
Would a' my life ha' ſerv'd ten reaſonable men,
And riſe contented too, and left enough for their friends.
You glutten at abuſes, never ſatisfied?
I am perſwaded thou devour'ſt more flouts
Then all thy body's worth, and ſtill a hungred!
A miſchiefe of that mawe; prethee ſeeke elſewhere,
Introth I am weary of abuſing thee;
Get thee a freſh Miſtris, thou'● make worke enough;
I do not thinke there's ſcorne enough in Towne
To ſerve thy turne, take the Court Ladies in,
And all their women to 'em, that exceed 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is this in earneſt, Lady?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Oh unſatiable!
Doſt thou count all this but an earneſt yet?
I'de thought I'de paid thee all the whole ſumme, truſt me;
Thou't begger my deriſion utterly
If thou ſtai'ſt longer, I ſhall want a laugh:
If I knew where to borrow a contempt
Would hold thee tack, ſtay and be hang'd thou ſhould'ſt then,
But thou'ſt no conſcience now to extort hate from me,
When one has ſpent all ſhe can make upon thee;
Muſt I begin to pay thee hire againe?
After I have rid thee twice? faith 'tis unreaſonable.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Say you ſo? I'le know that preſently.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Now he runs
To fetch my Uncle to this muſty bargaine,
But I have better ware alwaies at hand.
And lay by this ſtill when he comes to cheapen.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I met the Muſick now, yet cannot learne
What entertainment he receiv'd from her.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: There's ſome body ſet already, I muſt to't, I ſee,
Well, well, Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Hah, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Where e're you come you may well boaſt your conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She's loſt y'faith, enough, has fortune then
Remembred her great boy? ſhe ſeldome failes 'em.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: He was the unlikelieſt man at firſt, me thought,
To have my love, we never met but wrangled,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A pox upon that wrangling, ſay I ſtill,
I never knew it faile yet, where er't came;
It never comes but like a ſtorme of haile,
'Tis ſure to bring fine weather at the tayle on't,
There's not one match 'mongſt twenty made without it,
It fights i'th tongue, but ſure to agree i'th haunches.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: That man that ſhould ha' told me, when time was,
I ſhould ha' had him, had been laught at pitteouſly,
But ſee how things will change?

sp.speaker: Cun,
sp.l: Here's a heart feeles it — O the deceitfull promiſes of love!
What truſt ſhould a man put i'th lip of woman?
She kiſt me with that ſtrength, as if ſh'ad meant
To ha' ſet the faire print of her ſoule upon me.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I would ha' ſworne 'twould ne're ha' beene a match once.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ile heare no more, I'me mad to heare ſo much,
Why ſhould I aime my thoughts at better fortunes
Then younger brothers have? that's a Maid with nothing,
Or ſome old Soap-boylers Widow, without teeth,
There waits my fortune for me, ſeeke no farther.

div.stage: Enter Old Knight, and Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You tell me things, Sir Gregory, that cannot be,
She will not, nor ſhe dares not.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Would I were whipt then.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Ile make as little ſhow of love, Sir Gregory,
As ever woman did, you ſhall not know
You have my heart a good while.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Man will inſult ſo ſoone, 'tis his condition,
'Tis good to keep him off as long as we can,
I've much a do, I ſweare; and love i'th end
Will have his courſe, let Maids do what they can,
They are but fraile things, till they end in man.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What ſay you to this, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: This is ſomewhat handſome.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: And by that little wrangling that I fain'd,
Now I ſhall try how conſtant his love is,
Although't went ſore againſt my heart to chide him.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Alas poore Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Now y'are ſure of truth,
You heare her owne thoughts ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: They ſpeake indeed.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Go, you're a braineleſſe Coxe, a Toy, a Fop,
Ile go no farther then your name, Sir Gregory,
Ile right my ſelf there; were you from this place,
You ſhould perceive I'me heartily angry with you,
Offer to ſowe ſtrife 'twixt my Neece and I?
Good morrow Neece, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Many faire ones to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Go, your'e a Coxcombe. How doſt Neece this morning?
An Idle ſhallow foole: Slep'ſt thou well, Girle?
Fortune may very well provide thee Lordſhips,
For honeſty has left thee little manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: How am I bang'd a' both ſides?

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: Abuſe kindneſſe? Wil't take the ayre to day Neece?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: When you pleaſe, Sir,
There ſtands the Heyre behinde you I muſt take,
(Which I'de as live take, as take him I ſweare.)

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: La' you; do you hear't continued to your teeth now?
A pox of all ſuch Gregories; what a hand Neece lets fall her Scarfe.
Have I with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: No more y'feck, I ha' done, Sir:
Lady, your Scarfe's falne downe.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: 'Tis but your luck, Sir,
And doe's preſage the Miſtris muſt fall ſhortly,
You may weare it, and you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: There's a trick for you,
You'r parlouſly belov'd, you ſhould complaine.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yes, when I complaine, Sir,
Then do your worſt, there Ile deceive you Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: You are a Dolt, and ſo I leave you, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Ah ſirra, Miſtris, were you caught y'faith?
We overheard you all; I muſt not know
I have your heart, take heed a that, I pray,
I knew ſome Scarfe would come.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: He's quite gone, ſure:
Ah you baſe Coxcomb, couldſt thou come againe?
And ſo abus'd as thou waſt?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: 'Twould ha' kill'd
A ſenſible man, he would ha' gone to his Chamber,
And broke his heart by this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Or fixt a naked rapier in a wall,
Like him that earn'd his Knighthood e're he had it,
And then refus'd upon't, ran up to'th hilts.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yes, let him run for me, I was never brought up to't,
I never profeſt running i' my life.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: What art thou made on? thou tough villanous vermin,
Will nothing deſtroy thee?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yes, yes, aſſure your ſelfe
Unkinde words may do much.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Why, doſt thou want 'em?
I've e'ne conſum'd my ſpleene to help thee to 'em,
Tell me what ſort of words they be would ſpeed thee?
Ile ſee what I can do yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I'me much beholding to you,
Your'e willing to beſtow huge paines upon me.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I ſhould account nothing too much to rid thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I wonder you'd not offer to deſtroy me,
All the while your Uncle was here?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Why there thou betray'ſt thy houſe, we of the Old-Crafts
Were borne to more wit then ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I weare your favour here.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Would it might rot thy arme off: if thou knewſt
With what contempt thou haſt it, what hearts bitterneſſe,
How many cunning curſes came along with it,
Thoud'ſt quake to handle it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A pox, tak't againe then;
Who'd be thus plagu'd of all hands?

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: No, weare't ſtill,
But long I hope thou ſhalt not, 'tis but caſt
Upon thee, purpoſely to ſerve another
That has more right to't, as in ſome Countries they convey
Their treaſure upon Aſſes to their friends,
If mine be but ſo wiſe and apprehenſive
As my opinion gives him to my heart,
It ſtayes not long on thy deſertleſſe arme;
Ile make theee're I ha' done not dare to weare
Any thing of mine, although I give't thee freely;
Kiſſe it you may, and make what ſhew you can,
But ſure you carry't to a worthier man,
And ſo good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Hu hum, ha hum;
I han't the ſpirit now to daſh my braines out,
Nor the audacity to kill my ſelfe,
But I could cry my heart out, that's as good,
For ſo't be out no matter which way it comes,
If I can dye with a fillip, or depart
At hot cockles, what's that to any man?
If there be ſo much death that ſerves my turne there.
Every one knowes the ſtate of his owne body,
No Carrion kills a Kite, but then agen
There's Cheeſe will choak a Daw; time I were'dead ifaith,
If I knew which way without hurt or danger.
I am a Maiden-Knight, and cannot looke
Upon a naked weapon with any modeſty,
Elſe 'twould go hard with me, and to complaine
To Sir Perfidious the old Knight agen,
Were to be more abus'd; perhaps he would beat me well,
But ne're beleeve me;
And few men dye a beating, that were loſt too:
Oh, here's my friend, ile make my moane to him.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I cannot teare her memory from my heart,
That treads mine downe, was ever man ſo fool'd
That profeſt wit?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: O Cuningame?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir Gregory?
The choyce, the Victor, the Townes happy man?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sniggs, what doſt meane? come I to thee for comfort, and doſt abuſe me too?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Abuſe you? how Sir?
With juſtifying your fortune, and your joyes?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Pray hold your hand, Sir i've bin bold enough,
You come with a new way now; ſtrike me merrily,
But when a man's ſore beaten a both ſides already,
Then the leaſt tap in jeſt goes to the guts on him;
Wilt ha the truth? i'me made the ranckeſt aſſe
That e're was borne to Lordſhips.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What? no Sir;

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I had not thought my body could a yeelded
All thoſe foule ſcurvie names that ſhe has call'd me,
I wonder whence ſhe fecht 'em?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Is this credible?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: She pin'd this ſcarfe upon me afore her Unckle,
But his back turn'd, ſhe curſt me ſo for wearing on't,
The very brawne of mine arme has ak'd ever ſince,
Yet in a manner forc't me to weare't ſtill,
But hop't I ſhould not long; if good luck ſerve
I ſhould meet one that has more wit and worth
Should take it from me, 'twas but lent to me,
And ſent to him for a token.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I conceit it, I know the man
That lyes in wait for't, part with't by all meanes,
In any caſe, you are way-laid about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: How Sir? way-laid?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Pox of a Scarfe ſay I,
I prize my friends life 'bove a million on 'em,
You ſhall be rul'd, Sir, I know more then you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: If you know more then I, let me be rid on't,
Laſſe 'tis not for my wearing, ſo ſhe told me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No, no, give me't, the knave ſhall miſſe his purpoſe,
And you ſhall live.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I would, as long as I could, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No more replyes, you ſhall, Ile prevent this,
Pompey ſhall march without it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What, is't he?
My man that was?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Call him your deadly Enemy;
You give him too faire a name, you deale too nobly,
He beares a bloody minde, a cruell foe, Sir,
I care not if he heard me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: But do you heare, Sir?
Can't ſound with reaſon ſhe ſhould affect him?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Do you talk of reaſon? I never thought to have heard
Such a word come from you; reaſon in love?
Would you give that, no Doctor could e're give?
Has not a Deputy married his Cooke-maid?
An Aldermans Widow one that was her turne broach?
Nay, has not a great Lady brought her Stable
Into her Chamber: lay with her Horſe-keeper?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Did ever love play ſuch Jades tricks, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Oh thouſands, thouſands: Beware a ſturdy Clown ere while you live, Sir;
'Tis like a huſwifery in moſt Shires about us;
You ſhall ha' Farmers widowes wed thinne Gentlemen,
Much like your ſelfe, but put'em to no ſtreſſe;
What worke can they do, with ſmall trap-ſtick leggs?
They keep Clownes to ſtop gaps, and drive in peggs,
A drudgery fit for Hindes, e'ne back agen, Sir,
You'r ſafeſt at returning.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Thinke you ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: But how came this Clowne to be cal'd Pompey firſt?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Puſh, one good man Caeſar, a Pump-maker kerſen'd him;
Pompey he writes himſelfe, but his right name's Pumpey,
And ſtunke too when I had him, now he's cranke.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'me glad I know ſo much to quell his pride, Sir,
Walke you ſtill that way, Ile make uſe of this,
To reſolve all my doubts, and place this favour
On ſome new Miſtris, only for a try,
And if it meet my thoughts, Ile ſweare 'tis I. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is Pompey growne ſo malepert? ſo frampell?
The onely cutter about Ladies honours?
And his blade ſooneſt out?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Now, what's the newes, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Gre.
sp.l: I dare not ſay but good; oh excellent good, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I hope now you'r reſolv'd ſhe loves you, Knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Gr.
sp.l: Cuds me, what elſe Sir? that's not to do now.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: You would not think how deſperately you anger'd me,
When you belyed her goodneſſe; oh you vext me,
Even to a Palſey.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What a thing was that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: 'Tis, that 'tis; as I have hope of ſweetnes, the Scarfe's gone;
Worthy wiſe friend, I doat upon thy cunning,
We two ſhall be well matcht, our Iſſue male, ſure
Will be borne Counſellors; is't poſſible?
Thou ſhalt have another token out of hand for't;
Nay ſince the way's found, pitty thou ſhouldſt want, y'faith,
O my beſt joy, and deareſt.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Well ſaid, Neece,
So violent fore your Uncle? what will you do
In ſecret then?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Marry call me ſlave, and raſcall.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Your Scarfe — the Scarfe I gave you—

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Maſſe that's true Neece,
I ne're thought upon that; the Scarfe ſhe gave you- Sir?
What dumbe? no anſwer from you? the Scarfe?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I was way-laid about it, my life threatned;
Life's life, Scarfe's but a Scarfe, and ſo I parted from't.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Unfortunate woman! my firſt favour too?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Will you be ſtill an aſſe? no reconcilement
Twixt you and wit? are you ſo far fallen out,
You'l never come together? I tell you true,
I'me very lowſily aſham'd on you,
That's the worſt ſhame that can be;
Thus bayting on him: now his heart's hook't in,
Ile make him, e're I ha' done, take her with nothing,
I love a man that lives by his wits a life;
Nay leave, ſweet Neece, 'tis but a Scarfe, let it go.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: The going of it never grieves me, Sir.
It is the manner, the manner—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: O diſſembling Marmaſet! if I durſt ſpeake,
Or could be believ'd when I ſpeake,
What a tale could I tell, to make haire ſtand upright now?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, at your requeſt you ſhall perceive, Uncle,
With what renewing love I forgive this?
Here's a faire Diamond, Sir, Ile try how long
You can keep that?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Not very long, you know't too,
Like a cunning witch as you are.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Y'are beſt let him ha' that too.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: So I were, I think, there were no living elſe,
I thank you, as you have handled the matter.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why this is muſicall now, and Tueſday next
Shall tune your Inſtruments, that's the day ſet.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: A match, good Uncle.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Sir, you heare me too?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Oh very well, I'me for you.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: What e're you heare, you know my minde.

sp.speaker: Sir Gre.
