sp.p: I a — on't, too well, if I do not wonder how we two ſhall come together, I'me a beare whelpe? he talks of Tueſday next, as familiarly as if we lov'd one another, but 'tis as unlikely to me, as 'twas ſeven yeare before I ſaw her; I ſhall try his cunning, it may be he has a way was never yet thought on, and it had need to be ſuch a one, for all that I can thinke on will never do't; I looke to have this Diamond taken from me very ſpeedily, there|fore Ile take it off a my finger, for if it be ſeene, I ſhall be way-laid for that too.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: OH torture! torture! thou carrieſt a ſting i'thy taile,
Thou never brought'ſt good news i'thy life yet,
And that's an ill quality, leave it when thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Why you receive a bleſſing the wrong way, Sir,
Call you not this good newes? to ſave at once Sir
Your credit and your kinſmans life together;
Would it not vexe your peace, and gaule your worth?
T' have one of your name hang'd?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Peace, no ſuch words, boy.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Be thankfull for the bleſſing of prevention then.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: Le' me ſee, there was none hang'd out of our houſe ſince Brute,
I ha' ſearch't both Stowe, and Hollinſhead.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Ile ſee what Polychronicon ſaies anon too.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Twas a miraculous fortune that I heard on't.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I would thou'dſt never heard on't,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That's true too,
So it had ne're been done; to ſee the luck on't,
He was ev'n brought to Juſtice Aurums threſhold,
There had flewen ſorth a Mittimus ſtraight for Newgate;
And note the fortune too, Seſſions a Thurſday,
Jury cul'd out a Friday, Judgement a Saturday,
Dungeon a Sunday, Tyburne a Munday,
Miſeries quotidian ague, when't begins once,
Every day puls him, till he pull his laſt.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: No more, I ſay, 'tis an ill theame: where left you him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He's i'th Conſtables hands below i'th Hall, Sir,
Poore Gentleman, and his accuſer with him.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A Judges Sonne, 'tis thought ſo much the worſe too,
He'l hang his enemy, an't ſhall coſt him nothing,
That's a great priviledge.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Within there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Call up the folks i'th Hall. I had ſuch hope on him,
For a Scholler too, a thing thou ne're waſt fit for,
Therefore erected all my joyes in him;
Got a Welch Benefice in reverſion for him,
Deane of Cardigan, has his grace already,
He can marry and bury, yet ne're a haire on's face;
sp.stage: Enter Credulous, Sir Ruinous (as a Conſtable,) and Lady Gentry (as a man.)
sp.l: Like a French Vicar, and doe's he bring ſuch fruits to Town with him?
A thiefe at his firſt lighting? Oh good den to you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay, ſweet Sir, you'r ſo vext now, you'l grieve him,
And hurt your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Away, Ile heare no counſell;
Come you but once in ſeven yeare to your Uncle,
And at that time muſt you be brought home too?
And by a Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Oh ſpeake low, Sir,
Remember your owne credit, you profeſſe
You love a man a' wit, begin at home, Sir,
Expreſſe it i' your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay, Maſter Conſtable,
Shew your ſelf a wiſe man, 'gainſt your nature too.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Sir, no Diſh-porridgement, we have brought home
As good men as ye.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Out, a North-Brittaine Conſtable, that tongue
Will publiſh all, it ſpeaks ſo broad already;
Are you the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The unfortunate one, Sir,
That fell into the power of mercileſſe thieves,
Whereof this fellow, whom I'de call your kinſman,
As little as I could, (for the faire reverence
I owe to fame and yeares) was the prime villaine.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A wicked prime.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay, not ſo loud, ſweet father.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: The reſt are fled, but I ſhall meet with 'em,
Hang one of 'em I will certaine, I ha' ſwore it,
And 'twas my luck to light upon this firſt.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: A Cambridge man for this? theſe your degrees, Sir?
Nine yeares at Univerſity for this fellowſhip?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Take your voyce lower, deare Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's your loſſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That which offends me to repeat, the Money's whole, Sir,
'Tis i' the Conſtables hands there, a ſeal'd hundred,
But I will not receive it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: No? not the money, Sir,
Having confeſt 'tis all?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis all the Money, Sir,
But 'tis not all I loſt, for when they bound me,
They tooke a Diamond hung at my ſhirt ſtring,
Which feare of life made me forget to hide;
It being the ſparkling witneſſe of a Contract
'Twixt a great Lawyers daughter and my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I told you what he was; what does the Diamond
Concerne my Cozen, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No more did the Money,
But he ſhall anſwer all now.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: There's your conſcience,
It ſhewes from whence you ſprung.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sprung? I had leapt a thiefe,
Had I leapt ſome of your alliance.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Slave!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You prevent me ſtill.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: 'Slid, ſonne are you mad?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come, come, Ile take a legall courſe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Will you undo us all? what's your demand, Sir?
Now we're in's danger too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A hundred Marke, Sir,
I will not bate a doit.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: A hundred raſcals.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, finde 'em out in your own blood, and take 'em.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Go take your courſe, follow the Law, and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Does fury make you drunke? know you what you ſay?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A hundred dogs dungs, do your worſt.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You do I'me ſure; whoſe loud now?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What his owne asking?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Not in ſuch a caſe?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You ſhall have but three ſcore pound; ſpite a your teeth,
Ile ſee you hangd firſt.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And whats ſeven pound more man?
That all this coyle's about? ſtay, I ſay, he ſhall ha't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: It is your owne, you may do what you pleaſe with it;
Pardon my zeale, I would ha ſav'd you money;
Give him all his owne asking?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's that to you, Sir?
Be ſparing of your owne, teach me to pinch
In ſuch a caſe as this? go, go, live by your wits, go.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I practiſe all I can.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Follow you me, Sir,
And Maſter Conſtable come from the knave,
And be a witneſſe of a full recompence.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray ſtop the Conſtables mouth, what ere you do. Sir

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Yet agen? as if I meant not to do that my ſelfe,
Without your counſell? As for you, precious kinſman,
Your firſt years fruits in Wales ſhall go to rack for this,
You lye not in my houſe, Ile pack you out,
And pay for your lodging rather. Exeunt Knight, Ruin. and Lady.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Oh fie Cozen,
Theſe are ill courſes, you a Scholler too,

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I was drawne into't moſt unfortunately,
By filthy deboyſt company.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I, I, I,
'Tis even the ſpoile of all our youth in England;
What were they Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith ſo like, ſome on 'em,
They were ev'n the worſe agen.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Great Tobacco ſwivers,
They would go neere to rob with a pipe in their mouths.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What, no?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith leave it Cozen, becauſe my raſcals uſe it,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So they do meat and drinke, muſt worthy Gentlemen
Refraine their food for that? an honeſt man
May eat of the ſame pig ſome Parſon dines with,
A Lawyer and a foole feed of one Woodcock,
Yet one ne're the ſimpler, t'other ne're the wiſer;
'Tis not meat, drinke, or ſmoak, diſh, cup, or pipe,
Co-operates to the making of a knave,
'Tis the condition makes a ſlave, a ſlave,
There's London Philoſophy for you; I tell you cozen,
You cannot be too cautelous, nice, or dainty,
In your ſociety here, eſpecially
When you come raw from the Univerſity,
Before the world has hardned you a little,
For as a butter'd loafe is a Schollers breakfaſt there,
So a poacht Scholler is a cheaters dinner here,
I ha' knowne ſeven of 'em ſupt up at a Meale.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Why a poacht Scholler?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Cauſe he powres himſelf forth,
And all his ſecrets, at the firſt acquaintance,
Never ſo crafty to be eaten i'th ſhell,
But is outſtript of all he has at firſt,
And goes downe glibb, he's ſwallowed with ſharp wit,
Stead of Wine Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I ſhall think, Cozen,
A' your poch't Scholler, while I live.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Maſter Credulous,
Your Uncle wills you to forbeare the Houſe,
You muſt with me, I'me charg'd to ſee you plac'd
In ſome new lodging about Theeving Lane,
What the conceit's, I know not, but commands you
To be ſeene here no more, till you heare further.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Here's a ſtrange welcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: This is the World, Cozen;
When a mans fame's once poyſon'd, fare thee well Lad.
This is the happieſt cheat I e're claim'd ſhare in,
It has a two fold fortune, gets me coyne,
And puts him out of grace, that ſtood between me,
My fathers Cambridge Jewell, much ſuſpected
To be his Heyre, now there's a barre in's hopes.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: It chinks, make haſte.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The Goat at Smithfield Pens.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Zo, zo, zufficient. Maſter Cunningame?
I never have ill luck when I meet a wit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A wit's better to meet, then to follow then,
For I ha' none ſo good I can commend yet,
But commonly men unfortunate to themſelves,
Are luckieſt to their friends, and ſo may I be.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I run o're ſo much worth, going but in haſte from you,
All my deliberate friendſhip cannot equall.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis but to ſhew that you can place ſometimes,
Your modeſty a top of all your vertues. Exit Wit.
This Gentleman may pleaſure me yet agen;
I am ſo haunted with this broad brim'd hat,
Of the laſt progreſſe block, with the young hat-band,
Made for a ſucking Devill of two yeare old,
I know not where to turne my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mir,
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: More torture?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis rumor'd that you love me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A my troth Gentlewoman,
Rumour's as falſe a knave as ever piſt then,
Pray tell him ſo from me; I cannot faine
With a ſweet Gentlewoman, I muſt deale downe right.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I heard, though you diſſembled with my Aunt, Sir,
And that makes me more confident.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There's no falſhood,
But paies us our owne ſome way, I confeſſe
I fain'd with her, 'twas for a weightier purpoſe,
But not with thee, I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nor I with you then,
Although my Aunt enjoyn'd me to diſſemble,
To right her ſplene, I love you faithfully.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Light, this is worſe then 'twas.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I finde ſuch worth in you,
I cannot, nay I dare not dally with you,
For feare the flame conſume me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Here's freſh trouble,
This drives me to my conſcience, for 'tis fowle
To injure one that deales directly with me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I crave but ſuch a truth from your love, Sir,
As mine brings you, and that's proportionable.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A good Geometrician, ſhrew my heart;
Why are you out a' your wits, pretty plumpe Gentlewoman,
You talk ſo deſperately? 'tis a great happineſſe,
Love has made one on's wiſer then another,
We ſhould be both caſt away elſe;
Yet I love gratitude, I muſt requite you,
I ſhall be ſick elſe, but to give you me,
A thing you muſt not take, if you meane to live,
For a' my troth I hardly can my ſelfe;
No wiſe Phyſitian will preſcribe me for you.
Alas your ſtate is weake, you had need of Cordials
Some rich Electuary, made of a Sonne an Heire,
An elder brother in a Culliſſe, whole,
'T muſt be ſome wealthy Gregory, boyl'd to a Jelly,
That muſt reſtore you to the ſtate of new Gownes,
French Ruffs, and mutable head tires,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But where is he, Sir?
One that's ſo rich will ne're wed me with nothing.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Then ſee thy conſcience and thy wit together,
Wouldſt thou have me then, that has nothing neither?
What ſay you to Fop Gregory the firſt yonder?
Will you acknowledge your time amply recompenc'd?
Full ſatisfaction upon loves record?
Without any more ſuit, if I combine you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, by this honeſt kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You'r a wiſe Clyent,
To pay your fee before hand, but all do ſo,
You know the worſt already, that's thee beſt too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I know he's a foole,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You'r ſhrewdly hurt then;
This is your comfort, your great wiſeſt women
Pick their firſt husband ſtill out of that houſe,
And ſome will have 'em to chuſe, if they bury 20.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'me of their mindes, that like him for a firſt huſband,
To run youths race with him, 'tis very pleaſant,
But when I'me old, I'de alwaies wiſh a wiſer.
You may have me by that time; for this firſt buſineſſe,
Reſt upon my performance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: With all thankfulneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I have a project you muſt aid me in too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You binde me to all lawfull action, Sir,
Pray weare this ſcarfe about you;
I conjecture now—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There's a Court principle for't, one office muſt help another;
As for example, for your caſt a Manchits out a'th Pantry,
Ile allow you a Gooſe out a'th Kitchin.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis very ſociably done, Sir, farewell performance,
I ſhall be bold to call you ſo.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Do, ſweet confidence,
If I can match my two broad brim'd hats;
'Tis he, I know the Maggot by his head;
Now ſhall I learne newes of him, my pretious chiefe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I have been ſeeking for you i'th bowling Greene,
Enquir'd at Nettletons, and Anthonies Ordinary,
T'ha's vext me to the heart, looke, I've a Diamond here,
And it cannot finde a Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No? That's hard y'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: It does belong to ſome body, a — on him,
I would he had it, do's but trouble me,
And ſhe that ſent it, is ſo waſpiſh too,
There's no returning to her till't be gone.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Oh, ho, ah ſirrah, are you come?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What's that friend?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Do you note that corner ſparkle?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Which? which? which Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: At the Weſt end a'the Coller.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Oh I ſee't now.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis an apparent marke; this is the ſtone, Sir,
That ſo much blood is threatned to be ſhed for.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I pray?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A tunne at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: They muſt not find't I'me then, they muſt
Go where 'tis to be had.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis well it came to my hands firſt, Sir Gregory,
I know where this muſt go.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Am I diſcharg'd on't?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: My life for yours now. Drawes.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis diſcretion, Sir,
Ile ſtand upon my Guard all the while I ha't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Troth thou tak'ſt too much danger on thee ſtill,
To preſerve me alive.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis a friends duty, Sir,
Nay, by a toy that I have late thought upon,
Ile undertake to get your Miſtris for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Thou wilt not? wilt?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Contract her by a trick, Sir,
When ſhe leaſt thinks on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: There's the right way to't,
For if ſhe thinke on't once, ſhee'l never do't.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She doe's abuſe you ſtill then?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A —damnably,
Every time worſe then other; yet her Uncle
Thinks the day holds a tueſday; ſay it did, Sir,
She's ſo familiarly us'd to call me raſcall,
She'l quite forget to wed me by my owne name,
And then that marriage cannot hold in Law, you know.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Will you leave all to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Who ſhould I leave it to?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis our luck to love Neeces; I love a Neece too.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I would you did y'faith.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: But mine's a kinde wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I marry Sir, I would mine were ſo too.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No raſcall comes in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Troth, and mine has little elſe in hers.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Mine ſends me tokens,
All the world knows not on.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Mine gives me tokens too, very fine tokens,
But I dare not weare 'em.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Mine's kinde in ſecret.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: And there mine's a hell-cat.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: We have a day ſet too.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: 'Slid, ſo have we man,
But there's no ſigne of ever comming together.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Tell thee who 'tis, the old womans Neece.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is't ſhe?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I would your luck had been no worſe for mildneſſe;
But mum, no more words on't to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Foh!

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No blabbing as you love me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: None of our blood
Were ever bablers.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Prethee convey this Letter to her,
But at any hand let not your Miſtris ſee't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yet agen Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There's a Jewell in't,
The very art would make her doat upon't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Say you ſo?
And ſhe ſhall ſee't for that trick onely.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Remember but your Miſtris, and all's well.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay if I do not hang me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I believe you;
This is the onely way to returne a token,
I know he will do't now, cauſe he's charg'd to'th contrary.
He's the neareſt kin to a woman, of a thing
Made without ſubſtance, that a man can finde agen,
Some petticoat begot him, Ile be whipt elſe,
Engendring with an old paire of pawnde hoſe,
Lying in ſome hot chamber o're the Kitchin,
Very ſteame bred him,
He never came where Rem in Re e're grew;
The generation of a hundred ſuch
Cannot make a man ſtand in a white ſheet,
For 'tis no act in Law, nor can a Conſtable
Pick out a bawdy buſineſſe for Bridewell in't;
A lamentable caſe, he's got with a mans Urine, like a Mandrake.
How now? hah? what prodigious bravery's this?
A moſt prepoſterous Gallant, the Doublet ſits
As if it mockt the breeches.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Save you, Sir,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Has put his tongue in the fine ſuit of words too.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: How doe's the party?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Takes me for a Scrivener. Which of the parties?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Hum, ſimplicity betide thee—
I would faine heare of the party; I would be loath to go
Further with her; honour is not a thing to be dallied withall,
No more is reputation, no nor fame, I take it, I muſt not
Have her wrong'd when I'me abroad, my party is not
To be compell'd with any party in an oblique way;
'Tis very dangerous to deale with women;
May prove a Lady too, but ſhall be nameleſſe,
Ile bite my tongue out, e're it prove a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Upon my life I know her.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Not by me,
Know what you can, talke a whole day with me,
Y'are ne're the wiſer, ſhe comes not from theſe lips.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The old Knights Neece.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: 'Slid he has got her, pox of his heart that told him,
Can nothing be kept ſecret? let me entreat you
To uſe her name as little as you can, though.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Twill be ſmall pleaſure, Sir, to uſe her name.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I had intelligence in my ſolemne walks,
'Twixt Paddington and Pancridge, of a Scarfe,
Sent for a token, and a Jewell follow'd,
But I acknowledge not the receipt of any,
How e're 'tis carried, believe me Sir,
Upon my reputation I received none.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What, neither Scarfe nor Jewell?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: 'Twould be ſeene
Some where about me, you may well think that,
I have an arme for a Scarfe, as others have,
And dare to hang a Jewell too, and that's more
Then ſome men have, my betters a great deale,
I muſt have reſtitution, where e're it lights.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And reaſon good.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: For all theſe tokens, Sir,
Paſſe i' my name.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: It cannot otherwiſe be.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Sent to a worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I, that's to thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I'me wrong'd under that title.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I dare ſweare thou art,
'Tis nothing but Sir Gregories circumvention,
His envious ſpite, when thou'rt at Paddington,
He meets the gifts at Pancridge.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ah falſe Knight?
Falſe both to honour, and the Law of Arms?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What wilt thou ſay if I be reveng'd for thee?
Thou ſit as witneſſe?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I ſhould laugh in ſtate then.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ile fobb him, here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I ſhould be as glad as any man alive, to ſee him well fob'd, Sir; but now you talk of fobbing, I wonder the Lady ſends not forme according to promiſe? I ha' kept out a Towne theſe two daies, a purpoſe to be ſent for; I am almoſt ſtarv'd with walking.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Walking gets men a ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt true, Sir, I may ſpeake it by experience, for I ha' got a ſtomack ſix times, and loſt it agen, as often as a traveller from Chelſy ſhall loſe the ſight of Pauls, and get it agen.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Go to her, man.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Not for a Million, enfringe my oath? there's a toy call'd a vowe, has paſt betweene us, a poore trifle, Sir; Pray do me the part and office of a Gentleman, if you chance to meet a Footman by the way, in orange tawny ribbands, running before an empty Coach, with a Buzzard i'th Poope on't, direct him and his horſes toward the new River by Iſlington, there they ſhall have me looking upon the Pipes, and whiſtling. Exit Clow.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A very good note; this love makes us all Monkeyes,
But to my work: Scarfe firſt? and now a Diamond? theſe
Should be ſure ſignes of her affections truth;
Yet Ile go forward with my ſurer proofe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is't poſſible?
Nay here's his Letter too, there's a fine Jewell in't,
Therefore I brought it to you.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You tedious Mongrill! Is't not enough
To grace thee, to receive this from thy hand,
A thing which makes me almoſt ſick to do,
But you muſt talke too?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I ha' done

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Fall back,
Yet backer, backer yet, you unmannerly puppy,
Do you not ſee I'me going about to reade it?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay theſe are golden daies, now I ſtay by't,
She was wont not to endure me in her ſight at all,
The world mends, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: N●ece.
sp.l: What an ambiguous Superſcription's here?
To the beſt of Neeces. Why that title may be mine,
And more then her's:
Sure I much wrong the neatneſſed of his art;
'Tis certaine ſent to me, and to requite
My cunning in the carriage of my Tokens,
Us'd the ſame Fop for his.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: She nodded now to me, 'twill come in time.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: What's here? an entire Rubye, cut into a heart.
And this the word, Iſtud Amoris opus?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have heard him ſay that love is the beſt ſtone-cutter.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Why thou ſawcy iſſue of ſome travelling Sow-gelder,
What makes love? thy mouth? is it a thing
That ever will concerne thee? I do wonder
How thou dar'ſt think ont? haſt thou ever hope
To come i' the ſame roome where lovers are;
And ſcape unbrain'd with one of their velvet ſlippers?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Love tricks breake out I ſee, and you talk of ſlippers once,
'Tis not farre off to bed time.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Is it poſſible thou canſt laugh yet?
I would ha' undertooke to ha' kill'd a ſpider
With leſſe venome far, then I have ſpit at thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: You muſt conceive,
A Knight's another manner a peece of fleſh.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Back, Owles face.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: 'Tis my Uncles voyce, that:
Why keep you ſo farre off, Sir Gregory?
Are you afraid, Sir, to come neare your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is the proud heart come downe? I lookt for this ſtill.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: He comes not this way yet: Away, you dog-whelp;
Would you offer to come neare me, though I ſaid ſo?
Ile make you underſtand my minde in time;
Your running greedily like a hound to his breakfaſt,
That chops in head and all to beguile his fellowes;
I'me to be eaten, Sir, with Grace and leiſure,
Behaviour and diſcourſe, things that ne're trouble you;
After I have pelted you ſufficiently,
I tro you will learne more manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I'me wondring ſtill when we two ſhall come together?
Tueſday's at hand, but I'me as farre off, as I was at firſt,
I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Now Cuningame, Ile be reveng'd at large:
Lady, what was but all this while ſuſpition,
Is truth, full blowne now, my Neece weares your Scarfe.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Do but follow me, Ile place you instantly
Where you ſhall ſee her courted by Cuningame.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I go with greedineſſe; we long for things
That break our hearts ſometimes, there's pleaſures miſery,

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Where are thoſe gad-flies going? to ſome Junket now;
That ſome old humble-bee toles the yoūg one forth
To ſweet meats after kinde, let 'em looke to't,
The thing you wot on, be not miſt or gone,
I bring a Maiden-head, and I looke for one. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Cunningame (in diſcourſe with a Mask't Gen|tlewoman in a broad hat and ſcarf'd,) Neece at another doore.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Too manifeſt now, the Scarfe and all.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: It cannot be, you're ſuch a fearefull ſoule.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Ile give her cauſe of feare e're I part from her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Will you ſay ſo? Is't not your Aunts deſire too?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: What a diſſembling groane's that? ſhee'l for|ſwear't now.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I ſee my project takes, yonder's the grace on't.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Who would put confidence in wit againe,
I'me plagu'd for my ambition, to deſire
A wiſe man for a husband, and I ſee
Fate will not have us go beyond our ſtint,
We are allow'd but one diſh, and that's Woodcock,
It keeps up wit to make us friends and fervants of,
And thinks any thing's good enough to make us husbands
Oh that whores hat a' thine, a' the riding block,
A ſhade for lecherous kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Make you doubt on't?
Is not my love of force?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Yes, me it forces
To teare that ſorcerous ſtrumpet from th'imbraces.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Lady?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Oh thou haſt wrong'd the exquiſit'ſt love—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What meane you Lady?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Mine, you'l anſwer for't.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Alas, what ſeek you?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir, mine owne with loſſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You ſhall.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I never made ſo hard a bargaine.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Unjuſt man, let my wrath reach her,
As you owe vertue duty; your cauſe trips you,
Now Minion, you ſhall feele what loves rage is,
Before you taſte the pleaſure; ſmile you falſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: How can I chuſe? to ſee what paines you take,
Upon a thing will never thank you for't?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: See what things you women be, Lady,
When cloathes are taken for the beſt part of you?
This was to ſhow you, when you think I love you not,
How y'are deceiv'd ſtill, there the Morall lyes,
'Twas a trap ſet to catch you, and the only bait
To take a Lady nibling, is fine clothes;
Now I dare boldly thank you for your love,
I'me pretty well reſolv'd in't by this fit,
For a jealous ague alwaies uſhers it.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Now bleſſings ſtill maintaine this wit of thine,
And I'me an excellent fortune comming in thee,
Bring nothing elſe I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Not a groat I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be worthily welcome, take my faith for't,
Next opportunity ſhall make us.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The old Gentlewoman has fool'd her revenge ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Laſſe 'tis her part, ſhe knowes her place ſo well yonder;
Alwaies when women jumpe upon three ſcore,
Love ſhoves 'em from the chamber to the doore.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Thou art a precious ſhe-wit. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Cunningame (at one doore) Winy Pate, Ruinous, L. Ruinous, and Priſcian (at the other.)

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: FRiend, met in the harveſt of our deſignes,
Not a thought but's buſle.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I knew it man,
that made me provide theſe needfull Reapers,
Hooks, Rakers, Gleaners; wee'l ſing it home
With a melodious Horne-pipe; this is the Bond,
That as we further in your great affaire,
You'l ſuffer us to gleane, pick up for crums,
And if we ſnatch a handfull from the ſheafe,
You will not looke a churle on's.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Friend, wee'l ſhare
The ſheaves of gold, only the Love Aker
Shall be peculiar.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Much good do you, Sir,
Away, you know your way, and your ſtay; get you
The Muſick ready, while we prepare the dancers.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: We are a conſort of our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: And can ſtrike up luſtily.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You muſt bring Sir Fop.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: That's perfect enough.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Bring all the Fops you can, the more the better fare,
So the proverbe runs backwards. Exeunt Ruin. & Priſ.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Ile bring the Ladies. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Do ſo firſt, and then the Fops will follow;
I muſt to my father, he muſt make one. Exit.

div.stage: Enter two Servants with a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: While I diſpatch a buſineſſe with the Knight,
And I go with you. Well ſed, I thank you,
This ſmall Banquet will fusniſh our few Gueſts
With taſte and ſtate enough; one reach my Gowne,
The action craves it rather then the weather.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: There's one ſtaies to ſpeake with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Faith I know not what, Sir, a foole I thinke,
That ſome Brokers ſhop has made half a Gentleman;
Has the name of a Worthy too..

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Pompey? is't not?

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: That's he, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Alas poore fellow, prethee enter him, he will need too,
sp.stage: Enter ſecond Servant with a Gowne.
sp.l: He ſhall ſerve for a Witneſſe. Oh Gramercy:
If my friend Sir Gregory comes, you know him,
Entertaine him kindly. Oh Maſter Pompey, how is't man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: 'Snailes, I'me almoſt ſstarv'd with love, and cold, and one thing or other;
Has not my Lady ſent for me yet?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Not that I heare, ſure ſome unfriendly Meſſenger Is imployed betwixt you,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I was ne're ſo cold in my life, in my conſcience I have been ſeven mile in length, along the new River; I have ſeene a hundred ſtickle bags; I do not thinke but there's gudgeons too; 'twill ne're be a true water.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why thinke you ſo?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I warrant you, I told a thouſand Millers thumbs in it,
Ile make a little bold with your Sweet-meats.
And welcome Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: 'Tis is a ſtrange thing, I have no taſte in any thing.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Oh, that's Love, that diſtaſts any thing but it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: 'Tis worſe then Cheeſe in that point, may not a man breake his word with a Lady? I could finde in my heart and my hoſe too.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: By no meanes Sir, that breakes all the Lawes of Love.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Well, ile ne're paſſe my word without my deed to Lady, while I live agen, I would faine recover my taſte.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Well, I have newes to tell you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Good newes, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Happy newes, I help you away with a Rivall your Maſter beſtow'd

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Where for this plumbs ſake—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay liſten me.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I warrant you, Sir, I have two eares to one mouth,
I heare more then I eat, i'de ne're row by Queen Hive
While lived elſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I have a wife for him, and that ſhall witneſſe the Contract.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: The old one I hope, 'tis not the Lady?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Choak him firſt, 'tis one which thou ſhalt ſee,
See him, ſee him deceiv'd, ſee the deceit, only
The injunction is, you ſhall ſmile with modeſty.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ile ſimper ifaith, as cold as I am yet, the old one I hope.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, here's Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ud' ſo ſhelter, ſhelter, if you be ſeene
All's ravell'd out agen; ſtand there private,
And you'le finde the very opportunity
To call you forth, and place you at the Table.
You are welcome Sir, this Banquet will ſerve,
When it is crown'd with ſuch a dainty as you
Expect, and muſt have.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Tuſh, theſe ſweet-meats are but ſauce to that,
Well, if there be any honeſty or true word in a dreame,
She's mine owne, nay, and chang'd extreamely,
Not the ſame woman.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Who? not the Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg,
sp.l: No, not to me, the edge of her tongue is taken off,
Gives me very good words, turn'd upſide downe to me,
And we live as quietly as two Tortuſſes, if ſhe hold on
As ſhe began in my dreame. Soft Muſick.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay, if Love ſend forth ſuch Predictions,
You are bound to beleeve 'em, there's the watch-word
Of her coming, to your practis'd part now,
If you hit it, Aequus Cupido nobis.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I will warrant you Sir, I will give armes to
Your Gentry, looke you forward to your buſineſſe,
I am an eye behind you, place her in that Chaire,
And let me alone to grope her out.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Silence, Lady, your ſweet preſence illuſtrates
This homely roofe, and as courſe entertainment;
But where affections are both Hoſt and Gueſt,
They cannot meet unkindly, pleaſe you fit,
Your ſomething long ſtay made me unmannerly,
To place before you, you know this friend here,
He's my Gueſt, and more eſpecially,
That this our meeting might not be too ſingle,
Without a witneſſe to't.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.l: I came not unreſolv'd, Sir,
And when our hands are claſp'd in that firme faith
Which I expect from you; fame ſhall be bold
To ſpeake the lowdeſt on't: oh, you graſpe me.
Somewhat too hard friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: That's Loves eager will,
Ile touch it gentlier. Kiſſe her hand.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.l: That's too low in you,
Leſſe it be doubly recompenc'd in me. She kiſſes his hand.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Puh, I muſt ſtop my mouth, I ſhall be choakt elſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Come, wee'le not play and trifle with delayes,
We met to joyne theſe hands, and willingly
I cannot leave it till confirmation.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.p: One word firſt, how does your friend, kinde Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why do you mention him? you love him not?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I ſhall love you the leſſe if you ſay ſo, Sir,
In troth I love him, but 'tis you deceive him,
This flattering hand of yours does rob him now,
Now you ſteale his right from him, and I know
I ſhall have hate for't, his hate extreamly.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why I thought you had not come ſo weakly arm'd,
Upon my life the Knight will love you for't,
Exceedingly love you, for ever love you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I, you'le perſwade me ſo.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why he's my friend,
And wiſhes me a fortune equall with him,
I know, and dare ſpeake it for him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh, this hand betrayes him, you might remem|ber him in ſome courteſie yet at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I thank your help in't, here's to his health
Where e're he be.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ile pledge it were it againſt my health.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Oh. oh, my heart hops after twelve mile a day, upon a good returne, now could I walke three hundred mile a foot, and laugh forwards and backwards.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You'le take the Knights health Sir,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes, yes forſooth, oh my ſides! ſuch a Banquet once a weeke, would make me grow fat in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Well, now to cloſe our meeting, with the cloſe
Of mutuall hands and hearts, thus I begin,
Here in Heavens eye, and all loves ſacred powers,
(Which in my prayers ſtand propitious)
I knit this holy hand faſt, and with this hand
The heart that owes this hand, ever binding
By force of this initiating Contract
Both heart and hand in love, faith, loyalty,
Eſtate, or what to them belongs, in all the dues;
Rights and honours of a faithfull husband,
And this firme vow henceforth till death to ſtand
Irrevocable, ſeal'd both with heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Which thus I ſecond, but oh, Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Agen? this interpoſition's ill, beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Here in Heavens eye, and all Loves ſacred powers
I knit this holy hand faſt, and with this hand
The heart that owes this hand, ever binding
Both heart and hand in love, honour, loyalty,
Eſtate, or what to them belongs in all the dues,
Rights, and duties of a true faithfull wife;
And this firme Vow henceforth till death to ſtand,
Irrevocable ſeal'd both with heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A full agreement on both parts.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I, here's witneſſe of that.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay, I have over-reacht you Lady, and that's much,
For any Knight in England to over-reach a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I rejoyce in my deceit, I am a Lady
Now, I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Good morrow Lady Fop.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: 'Snailes, i'me gull'd, made a worſhipfull aſſe, this is not my Lady.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: But it is Sir, and true as your dreame told you,
That your Lady was become another woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ile have another Lady Sir, if there were no more Ladies in London, blinde-man buffe is an unlawfull Game.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Come, downe on your knees firſt, and thanke your ſtars.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A fire of my ſtars, I may thanke you I think.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: So you may pray for me, and honour me,
That have preſerv'd you from a laſting torment,
For a perpetuall comfort; did you call me friend?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I pray pardon me for that, l did miſcall you, I confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And ſhould I receiving ſuch a thankfull name
Abuſe it in the act? ſhould I ſee my friend
Bafful'd, diſgrac'd, without any reverence
To your title to be call'd ſlave, raſcall?
Naay curſt to your face, fool'd, ſcorn'd, beaten downe
With a womans peeviſh hate, yet I ſhould ſtand
And ſuffer you to be loſt, caſt away?
I would have ſeene you buried quick firſt,
Your ſpurrs of Knight-hood to have wanted rowels,
And to be kickt from your heeles; ſlave, raſcall?
Heare this tongue?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My deareſt Love, ſweet Knight, my Lord, my Husband.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: So, this is not ſlave and raſcall then.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What ſhall your eye command, but ſhall be done,
In all the duties of a loyall wife?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Good, good, are not curſes fitter for you? wer't not better
Your head were broke with the handle of a fanne,
Or your noſe bor'd with a ſilver bodkin?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, I will be a ſervant in your Lady.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Pox, but you ſhall not, ſhe's too good for you,
This contract ſhall be a nullity, ile breake't off,
And ſee you better beſtow'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: 'Slid, but you ſhall not Sir, ſhe's mine owne, And I am hers, and we are one anothers lawfully, and let me ſee him that will take her away by the Civill Law, if you be my friend keepe you ſo, if you have done me a good turne, do not hit me ith' teeth with't, that's not the part of a friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: If you be content —

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Content? I was never in better contention in my life,
Ile not change her for both the Exchanges, New or the Old;
Come, kiſſe me boldly.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Give you joy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I thanke you as much as though I did, you are beloved of Ladies, you ſee we are glad of un|der women.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ladies? let not Ladies be diſgrac'd, you are as it were a married man, and have a Family, and for the parties ſake that was unnam'd before, being Peſe-cod time, I am appeas'd, yet I would wiſh you make a ruler of your tongue.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay, no diſſention here, I muſt bar that,
And this (friend) I entreat you, and be advis'd,
Let this private contract be yet conceal'd,
And ſtill ſupport a ſeeming face of love
Unto the Lady; marke how it availes you,
And quits all her ſcornes, her Unckle is now hot
In purſuit of the match, and will enforce her
Bend her proud ſtomack, that ſhe ſhall proffer
Her ſelfe to you, which when you have flouted,
And laught your fill at, you ſhall ſcorne her off
With all your diſgraces trebled upon her,
For there the pride of all her heart will bow,
When you ſhall foot her from you, not ſhe you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Good ifaith; ile continue it, i'de faine laugh at the old fellow too, for he has abus'd me as ſcurvily as his Neece, my Knight-hood's upon the ſpur, wee'le go to Bed, and then to Church as faſt as we can.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I do wonder I do not heare of the Lady yet.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The good minute may come ſooner then you are aware of,
I do not thinke but 'twill e're night yet as neare as 'tis.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Well, I will go walke by the new River in that meditation, I am o're ſhooes I'me ſure upon the dry bank, this gullery of my Maſter will keepe me company this two houres too, if love were not an enemy to laughter I ſhould drive away the time well enough; you know my walke Sir, if ſhe ſends, I ſhall be found angling, for I will try what I can catch for luck ſake, I will fiſh faire for't.
sp.l: Oh Knight that thou ſhould'ſt be gull'd ſo; ha, ha, it does me good at heart,
But oh Lady, thou tak'ſt downe my merry part. Exit

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Here friend.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: All's afoot, and will go ſmooth away,
The woman has conquer'd the women, they are gone,
Which I have already complain'd to my Father,
Suggeſting that Sir Gregory is falne off
From his charge, for neglects and ill uſage,
And that he is moſt violently bent
On Gentries wife (whom I have call'd a widow)
And that without moſt ſudden prevention
He will be married to her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Foot, all this is wrong,
This wings his purſuit, and will be before me; I am loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: No, ſtay, you ſhall not go
But with my Father, on my wit let it lye,
You ſhall appeare a friendly aſſiſtant,
To helpe in all affaires, and in execution
Helpe your ſelfe only.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Would my beleefe
Were ſtronge in this aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: You ſhall credit it,
And my wit ſhall be your ſlave if it deceive you.
My Father —

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Oh Sir, you are well met, where's the Knight your friend?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir, I thinke your Sonne has told you.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Shall I ſtand to tell't agen? I tell you he loves,
But not my Kinſ-woman, her baſe uſage,
And your ſlack performance which he accuſes moſt
Indeed, has turn'd the Knights heart upſide downe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Ile curbe her for't, can he be but recover'd,
He ſhall have her, and ſhe ſhall be dutifull,
And loue him as a wife too.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: With that condition Sir,
I dare recall him were he enter'd the Church,
So much intereſt of love I aſſure in him.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Sir, it ſhall be no loſſe to you if you do.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: I, but theſe are words ſtill, will not the deeds Be wanting at the recovery, if it ſhould be agen?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why here foole, I am provided, five hunder'd in earneſt,
Of the thouſands in her Dower, but were they married once,
I'de cut him ſhort enough, that's my agreement.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I, now I perceive ſome purpoſe in you, Father.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: But wherefore is ſhe then ſtolne out of doores to him?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: To him? oh fye upon your errour, ſhe has ano|ther objett, beleeve it Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I never could perceive it.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I did Sir, and to her ſhame I ſhould ſpeake it,
To my owne ſorrow I ſaw it, dalliance,
Nay dotage with a very Clowne, a Foole.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: Wit and wantons? nothing elſe? nothing elſe?
She love a Foole? ſhe'le ſooner mate a foole
Of a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I, my friend complaines ſo,
Sir Gregory ſayes flatly ſhe makes a foole of him,
And theſe bold circumſtances are approv'd;
Favours have been ſent by him, yet he ignorant
Whither to carry 'em; they have been underſtood,
And taken from him, certaine Sir, there is
An unſuſpected fellow lyes conceal'd,
What, or where e're he is, theſe ſlight neglects
Could not be of a Knight elſe.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Well Sir, you have promis'd (if we recover him Unmarried) to ſalve all theſe old bruiſes?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ile do my beſt Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I ſhall thanke you, coſtly Sir, and kindly too.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Will you talke away the time here Sir, and come behirtde all your purpoſes?

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.l: Away good Sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Then ſtay a little good Sir, for my adviſe,
Why Father are you broke? your wit begger'd,
Or are you at your wits end? or out of
Love with wit? no trick of Wit to ſurprize
Thoſe deſignes, but with open Hue and Cry,
For all the world to talke on? this is ſtrange,
You were not wont to slubber a project ſo.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Can you helpe at a pinch now? ſhew your ſelfe
My ſonne, go too, I leave this to your wit,
Becauſe ile make a proofe on't.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: 'Tis thus then,
I have had late intelligence, they are now
Buxſome as Bachus Froes, revelling, dancing,
Telling the Muſicks numbers with their feet,
Awaiting the meeting of premoniſht friends,
That's queſtionleſſe, little dreading you,
Now Sir, with a dexterous trick indeed, ſuddaine
And ſufficient were well, to enter on um
As ſomething like the abſtract of a Maſque;
What though few perſons? if beſt for our purpoſe
That commends the project.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This takes up time.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Not at all, I can preſently furniſh
With looſe diſguiſes that ſhall fit that Scene.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why what wants then?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nothing but charge of Muſick,
That muſt be paid you know.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: That ſhall be my charges, ile pay the Muſick,
What e're it coſt.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: And that ſhall be all your charge,
Now on, I like it, there will be wit in't Father.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I will neither diſtruſt his wit nor friendſhip,
Yet if his maſter braine ſhould be o're-throwne
My reſolution now ſhall ſeize mine owne. Exit

div.stage: Enter Neece, Lady Ruinous, Gardianeſſe, Ruinous, Priſcian (with inſtrumenes maſqu't.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Nay, let's have Muſick, let that ſweet breath at leaſt
Give us her ayrie welcome, 'twill be the beſt
I feare this ruin'd receptacle will yeeld,
But that moſt freely.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: My welcome followes me,
Elſe I am ill come hither, you aſſure me
Still Mr. Cuningame will be here, and that it was
His kinde entreaty that wiſht me meet him.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Elſe let me be that ſhame unto my Sex,
That all beleefe may fly um.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Continue ſtill
The Knights name unto my Gardianeſſe,
She expects no other.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: He will, he will aſſure you
Lady, Sir Gregory will be here, and ſuddainely
This Muſick fore-ran him, is't not ſo conſorts?

sp.speaker: Ruin,
sp.l: Yes Lady, he ſtaies on ſome device to bring along
Such a labour he was buſie in, ſome witty device.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: 'Twill be long e're he comes then, for wit's a great Labour to him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, well, you'le agree better one day.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Scarce two I think.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Such a mock-begger ſuit of clothes as led me
Into the fooles paire of Dice, with dewze ace,
He that would make me Miſtris Cun, Cun, Cunnie,
He's quite out of my minde, but I ſhall ne're
Forget him while I have a hole in my head,
Such a one I think would pleaſe you better,
Though he did not abuſe you.

sp.speaker: Ruin,
sp.l: Fye, ſpeake well of him now,
Your Neece has quitted him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I hope ſhe has,
Elſe ſhe looſes me for ever; but for Sir Gregory,
Would he were come. I ſhall ill anſwer this
Unto your Unckle elſe.

sp.speaker: Nei.
sp.l: You know 'tis his pleaſure
I ſhould keepe him company.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I, and ſhould be your owne
If you did well too, Lord, I do wonder
At the niceneſſe of you Ladies now a dayes,
They muſt have Husbands with ſo much wit forſooth.
Worſhip and wealth were both wont to be
In better requeſt I'me ſure, I cannot tell,
But they get ne're the wiſer children that I ſee.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: La, la, la, la, Sol, this Muſick breathes in vaine,
Me thinks 'tis dull to let it move alone,
Let's have a female motion, 'tis in private,
And wee'le grace't our ſelves how ever it deſerves.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: What ſay you Gardianeſſe?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: 'Laſſe i'me weary with the walke,
My jaunting dayes are done.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Come, come, we'le fetch her in by courſe, or elſe,
She ſhall pay the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Nay, ile have a little for my money then.

div.stage: The Dance, a Cornet is winded.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Hark? upon my life the Knight; 'tis your friend,
This was the warning-peece of his approach.

div.stage: Enter Old Knight, Witty-pate, Cuningame, Maſqu'd, and take them to dance.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Ha? no words but mum? well then,
We ſhall need no counſell-keeping

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Yes, feare nothing.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Feare? why do you tell me of it?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Your Unckles here.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Aye me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: We have caught 'em.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Thanke my wit Father.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Which is the Knight thinke you?

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: I know not, he will be found when be ſpeakes,
No Maske can diſguiſe his tongue.

sp.speaker: Wity.
sp.l: Are you charg'd?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Are you awake?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I'me anſwer'd in a queſtion.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Next change we meet, we looſe our hands no more.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Are you prepar'd to tye 'em?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Yes,
You muſt go with me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Whether Sir? not from my charge beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She goes a long.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Will you ventur and my Unckle here?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: His ſtay's prepar'd for. Exeunt they two.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: 'Tis the Knight ſure, ile follow.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How now, the Muſick tyr'd before us?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Yes Sir, we muſt be paid now.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Oh, that's my charge Father.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: But ſtay, where are our wanton Ladies gone?
Sonne, where are they?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Onely chang'd the roome in a change, that's all ſure.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Ile make 'em all ſure elſe, and then returne to you.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: You muſt pay for your Muſick firſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Muſt? are there muſty Fidlers? are Beggers choo|ſers now?
Ha? why Witty-pate, Sonne, where am I?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: You were dancing e'ne now, in good meaſure Sir,
Is your health miſcarried ſince? what ayle you, Sir?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Death, I may be gull'd to my face, where's my Neece?
What are you?

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: None of your Neece, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How now? have you loud Inſtruments too? ile heare
No more I thanke you, what have I done tro
To bring theſe feares about me? Sonne, where am I?

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.l: Not where you ſhould be, Sir, you ſhould be paying
For your Muſick, and you are in a maze.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Oh, is't ſo, put up, put up, I pray you,
Here's a crowne for you.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Piſh, a crowne?

sp.speaker: Ru. Priſ.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, a crowne?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Which way do you laugh? I have ſeene a crowne
Has made a Conſort laugh heartily.

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.l: Father,
To tell you truth, theſe are no ordinary
Muſitians, they expect a bounty
Above their punctuall deſert.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A — on your Puncks, and their deſerts too.
Am I not cheated all this while thinke you?
Is not your pate in this?

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.l: If you be cheated,
You are not to be Indicted for your owne goods,
Here you trifle time to market your bounty
And make it baſe, when it muſt needs be free
For ought I can perceive.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Will you know the loweſt price, Sir?

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.l: That I will Sir, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Unleſſe I was diſcover'd, and they now fled
Home agen for feare, I am abſolutely beguil'd,
That's the beſt can be hop'd for.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Faith 'tis ſomewhat too deare yet, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: There's not a Denier to be bated, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Now Sir, how deare is it?

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.l: Bate but the tother ten pound?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Not a Bawbee, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. R.
sp.l: How? bate ten pound? what's the whole ſumme then?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Faith Sir, a hundred pound, with much a doe,
I got fifty bated, and faith Father, to ſay truth,
'Tis reaſonable for men of their faſhion.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: La, la, la, downe, a hunder'd pound? la, la, la,
You are a Conſort of Theeves, are you not?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: No Muſitians Sir, I told you before.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Fiddle faddle, is it not a robbery? a plaine robbery?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: No, no, no, by no meanes Father, you have receiv'd
For your money, nay, and that you cannot give back,
'Tis ſomewhat deare I confeſſe, but who can helpe it?
If they had been agreed with before hand,
'Twas ill forgotten.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And how many ſhares have you in this? I ſee my force,
Caſe up your Inſtruments, I yield, here, as rob'd and
Taken from me, I deliver it.

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.p: No Sir, you have perform'd your promiſe now, which was, to pay the charge of Muſick, that's all.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I have heard no Muſick, I have receiv'd none, Sir, There's none to be found in me, nor about me.

sp.speaker: VVitty.
sp.l: Why Sir, here's witneſſe againſt you, you have danc'd,
And he that dances acknowledges a receit
Of Muſick.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I deny that Sir, looke you, I can dance without Muſick, do you ſee Sir? and I can ſing without it too; you are a conſort of Theeves, do you heare what I do?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Pray you take heed Sir, if you do move the Mu|ſick agen, it may coſt you as much more.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.p: Hold, hold, ile depart quietly, I need not bid you farewell, I think now, ſo long as that hundred pound laſts with you.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ha, ha, am I ſnapt ifaith?
Oh, Sir, Perfidious.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I, I, ſome howling anotherwhile, Muſick's too damnable deare.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Oh Sir, my heart-ſtrings are broke, if I can but live to tell you the tale I care not, your Neece my charge is —

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.p: What, is ſhe ſick?

sp.speaker: Gard,
sp.p: No, no Sir, ſhe's luſtity well married.

sp.speaker: O.K.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Oh, to that cunning diſſembler, Cuningame.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Ile hang the Prieſt, firſt, what was he?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Your Kinſman Sir, that has the Welch Benefice.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I ſav'd him from the Gallowes to that end, good, is there any more?

sp.speaker: Garde
sp.p: And Sir Gregory is married too.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: To my Neece too, I hope, and then I may hang her.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: No Sir, to my Neece, thank Cupid; and that's all that's likely to recover me, ſhe's Lady Fop now, and I am One of her Aunts I thanke my promotion.

div.stage: Enter Credulous, Cuningame, Neece, Sir Gregory, and Mirabell.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: I hate perform'd your beheſt Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: What have you perform'd Sir?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I muſt excuſe my Couſen in this act,
If you can excuſe your ſelfe for making him
A Prieſt, there's the moſt difficult anſwer
I put this practiſe on him as from your deſire,
A truth, a truth Father.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: I proteſt Sir, he tells you truth, he mov'd me to't in your name.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I protest Sir, he told you a lye in my name, and were you ſo eaſie Mr. Credulous to beleeve him?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: If a man ſhould not beleeve his Couſen Sir, whom ſhould he beleeve?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Godden to you good Mr. Couſen Cuningame,
And your faire Bride, my Couſen Cuningame too,
And how do you, Sir Gregory, with your faire Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: A little better then you would have had me, I thanke you Sir, the dayes of Puppy, and Slave, and Raſ|call are pretty well blowne over now, I know Crabs from Verjuyce, I have tryed both, and thoud'ſt give me thy Neece for nothing i'de not have her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I thinke ſo Sir Gregory, for my ſake you would not.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I wo'd thou had'ſt ſcap'd her too, and then ſhe had dyed of the greene ſickneſſe, know this, that I did marry in ſpight, and I will kiſſe my Lady in ſpight, and love her in ſpight, and beget children of her in ſpight, and when I dye they ſhall have my Lands in ſpight; this was my reſolution, and now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: How ſpightfull are you now, Sir Gregory?
Why looke you, I can love my deareſt Husband,
With all the honours, duties, ſweet embraces,
That can be throwne upon a loving man.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: — This is afore your Unckles face, but be|hinde his back in private you'le ſhew him another tale.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You ſee Sir, now the irrecoverable ſtate of all theſe things before you, come out of your muſe, they have been but wit weapons, they were wont to love the play.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Let me alone in my muſe a little Sir, I will wake to you anon.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: U'd ſo, your friend Pompey, how will you anſwer him?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Very well, if you'le but ſecond it, and help me.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I do heare ſtrange ſtories, are Ladies things ob|noxious?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Oh, the diſſembling falſeſt wretch is come.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: How now Lady?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Let me come to him, and in ſtead of love
Let me have revenge.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Pray you now, will you firſt examine, whither he be guilty or no.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: He cannot be excus'd,
How many Meſſengers (thou perjur'd man)
Haſt thou return'd with Vowes and Oathes? that thou
Wouldſt follow, and never till this unhappy houre
Could I ſet eye of thee, ſince thy falſe dye
Drew my heart to it? oh I could teare thee now,
In ſtead of ſoft embraces, pray give me leave—

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Faith this was ill done of you Sir, if you pro|mis'd otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: By this hand, never any Meſſenger came at me ſince the firſt time I came into her company; that a man ſhould be wrong'd thus?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Did not I ſend thee Scarfes and Diamonds?
And thou returnd'ſt me letters, one with a faife heart in't.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: On fye to receive favours, returne falſe-hoods, and hold a Lady in hand —

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Will you believe me Sir? if ever I receiv'd Dia|monds, or Scarfe, or ſent any Letter to her, would this Sword might ne're go through me.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Some bad Meſſengers have gone betweene you then.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Take him from my fight, if I ſhall ſee to mor|row.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Pray you forbeare the place, this diſcontent may impaire her health much.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Foot, if a man had been in any fault 'twould ne're have griev'd him, Sir, if you'le beleeve.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nay, nay, proteſt no more, I do believe you,
But you ſee how the Lady is wrong'd by't;
She has caſt away her ſelfe it is to be fear'd,
Againſt her Unckles will, nay, any conſent,
But out of a meere neglect, and ſpight to her ſelfe,
Married ſuddenly without any advice.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Why who can helpe it? if ſhe be caſt away ſhe may thanke her ſelfe, ſhe might have gone further and far'd worſe; I could do no more then I could do, 'twas her owne pleaſure to command me that I ſhould not come till I was ſent for, I had been with her every minute of an houre elſe.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Truly I believe you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Night and day ſhe might have commanded me, and that ſhe knew well enough; I ſaid as much to her between her and I, yet I proteſt ſhe's as honeſt a Lady for my part, that i'de ſay if ſhe would ſee me hang'd, if ſhe be cast away I cannot helpe it, ſhe might have ſtay'd to have ſpoke with a man.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Well, 'twas a hard miſſe on both parts.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: So 'twas, I was within one of her, for all this croſſe luck, I was ſure I was between the Knight and home.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Not gone yet? oh my heart! none regard my health?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Good Sir, forbeare her ſight a while, you heare how ill ſhe brookes it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Fooliſh woman, to over-throw her fortunes ſo; I ſhall thinke the worſe of a Ladies wit while I live for't— I could almoſt cry for anger, if ſhe ſhould miſcarry now, 'twould touch my conſcience a little, and who knowes what love and conceit may do? what would people ſay as I go along? there goes he that the Lady dyed for love on, lam ſure to heare on't ith' streets. I ſhall weepe before hand; fooliſh woman, I do grieve more for thee now then I did love thee before; well, go thy waies, would'ſt thou ſpare thy Husbands head and breake thine owne heart? if thou hadſt any wit, I would ſome other had been the cauſe of thy undoing, I ſhall be twitted i'th teeth with't, i'me ſure of that, fooliſh Lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: So, ſo, this trouble's well ſhooke off, Unckle, how dee? there's a Dowrie due, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: We have agreed it, ſweeteſt,
And finde your Unckle fully recover'd, kinde to both of us.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: To all the rest I hope;

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Never to thee, nor thee, eaſie couſen Credulous,
Was your wit ſo raw?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith yours Sir, ſo long ſeaſon'd
Has been faulty too, and very much to blame,
Speaking it with reverence, Unckle.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes faith, Sir, you have paid as deare for your time as any man here.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p:
I Sir, and ile reckon it to him. Imprimis, The firſt preface cheat of a paire of peeces to the Beggers, you
remember that I was the example to your bounty there, I ſpake Greeke, and Syriacke, Sir, you underſtand me now. Next, the Robbery put upon your indulgent Couſen, which indeed was no Robbery, no Conſtable, no Juſtice, no Thiefe, but all Cheaters; there was a hunder'd Mark, mark you that. Laſtly, this memorable 100. pounds worth of Muſick, this was but cheats and wit too, and for the aſſiſtance, this Gentleman to my Couſen (for which I am to have a Fee) that was a little practice of my wit too, Fa|ther; will you come to compoſition yet, Father?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Yes faith Sir, do, two hunder'd a yeare will be eaſier then ſo much weekly, I do not think he's barren if he ſhould be put to't agen.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why this was the day I look'd for, thou ſhalt have't,
And the next cheat makes it up three hunder'd;
Live thou upou thy ten pound Vicarage,
Thou get'ſt not a penny more, here's thy full
Hire now.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Why there was the ſumme of all my wit Father,
To ſhove him out of your favour, which I fear'd
Would have diſ-inherited me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Moſt certaine it had,
Had not thy wit recover'd it; is there any here
That had a hand with thee?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Yes, all theſe Sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Nephew, part a hunder'd pound amongſt 'em,
Ile repay it; wealth, love me as I love wit;
When I dye,
Ile build an Almeſ-houſe for decay'd wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ile entertaine one in my life time; Schollar, you ſhall be my Chaplaine, I have the gift of twenty Bene|fices, ſimple as I am here.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Thankes my great Patron.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Sir, your Gentry and your name ſhall both be rais'd as high as my fortunes can reach 'em, for your friends ſake.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Something will be in my preſent power, the future more,
You ſhall ſhare with me.

sp.speaker: Ruin. and VVife.
sp.l: Thankes worthy Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir, I would beg one thing of you?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: You can beg nothing of me.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Oh Sir, if ſhe begs, there's your power over her.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: She has begg'd me for a foole already, but 'tis no matter,
I have begg'd her for a Lady that ſhe might have been,
That's one for another.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nay, but if ſhe beg—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Let her beg agen then.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: That your man Pompeyes Coat may come over his eares backe agen, I would not he ſhould be loſt for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Well, 'tis granted, for mine owne ſake.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.l: Ile entreat it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Why then 'tis granted for your ſake.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Come, come, downe with all weapons now, 'tis
Muſicke time,
So it be purchas'd at an eaſie rate;
Some have receiv'd the knocks, ſome given the hits,
And all concludes in love, there's happy wits. Exeunt

div.head: The Epilogue at the reviving of this Play.
div.l: WE need not tell you Gallants, that this night
The VVits have jumpt, or that the Scenes hit right,
'Twould be but labour loſt for to excuſe
VVhat Fletcher had to do in, his brisk Muſe
VVas ſo Mercuriall, that if he but writ
An Act, or two, the whole Play riſe up wit.
Wee'le not appeale unto thoſe Gentlemen
Judge by their Clothes, if they ſit right, nor when
The Ladies ſmile, and with their Fannes delight
To whiske a climb aſide, then all goes right:
'Twas well receiv'd before, and we dare ſay,
You now are welcome to no vulgar Play.

back.trailer: Here endeth Wit at ſeverall Weapons.
